story:
From Boyle Heights To The Blob

The kids in Boyle Heights grow up in one of the most dangerous neighborhoods in Los Angeles - there's a reported average of 11 violent crimes every week. Many of the kids lack positive role models and face challenges from the many gangs nearby, access to drugs, and various family struggles. What if these kids could find hope?

Woodleaf Camp is a few hours north of LA in Challenge, CA. This place has Ridge Runners, ropes courses, swimming, and the blob - just to name a few. Woodleaf is owned by YoungLife, a Christian organization whose mission is that every adolescent will have the opportunity to meet Jesus Christ and follow him.

We are a group of Biola University graduates who live in a house owned by our English professor in the heart of Boyle Heights. We have already developed many friendships with the kids in this neighborhood by hosting weekly events at our home, tutoring at their schools, and more.

Camp will have a profound and lasting impact on the lives of these kids!


We Want To Go To Camp!

(You're supporting us...)

*** COMPLETELY FUNDED!!! ***


We'll Be Their Leaders!

(your donations don't go to us)


What We Need & What You Get

Our Expenses

  • $5,000 gets 10 kids to get to camp ($500 per kid). This includes all meals, camp activities, and lodging.
  • $800 covers the rental of a 15 passenger van and gas for travel.
  • $400 covers processing fees. Indiegogo takes a 3% cut, 4% goes to third party payment processors.


Your Perks


If we don’t reach our entire goal, we will use all the funds to get as many kids as possible to camp. If we exceed our goal, we will try to get more than 10 kids to camp, or use it to get kids to camp next summer!

Check out our Facebook Page!


A HUGE Impact

See how meaningful camp has been to past Woodleaf campers,

"The most meaningful thing this week was cabin time, just talking to friends about struggles in my life."

"I learned that I needed​ to let go of my fears and trust Christ."

"This was the best week of my life...for real."


You can help to change a kid's life!


Other Ways To Help

We know some people just can’t contribute financially, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help! You can:

  • Spread the word through social media to get the word out to those who may want to help. Use the simple-to-use share tools on this page!
  • Pray for the young people in Boyle Heights and those of us who are ministering to them.


Thanks so much for your support!!

story:
Dear Friends, family and any soul who may have ventured upon this page! 

Thankyou for already taking the time to have a peak at what I am up to. 

I am OVER THE MOON to have been accepted on a project in Thailand this January. Spark! circus .. is a small NGO that I have come across during my previous adventures in Thailand. Always in awe of what they do.. finally after a couple of years of circus training I feel READY. 

Now a more confident clown.. it's time to share the wonderful ways of play and improvisation with some children in need of laughter. I will be working for one month with the children living on the border or burma and thailand. Performing and teaching... bringing fun, education and excitement to their lives. 

Please support my venture and read below as to where your donations will go. 

Please note EVERY PENNY goes to the organisation.. not me. Volunteers cover all of their personal travel/ accommodation and food costs. 

I would like to take as much as possible with me when I go.. please be generous! Only two weeks to go !! 

BIG love to all .. may your dreams become reality in 2014.. I think mine will :D


To see a glimpse of me as a performer.. click here https://vimeo.com/81098082

To read more about spark circus read here sparkcircus.org 


Where your Money goes...

Each camp will receive a kit for the children, including:

  • circus toys for the children (such as hula hoops, poi, juggle balls, diabolos, ...)
  • equipment for handcrafting so the children can make their own toys and costumes for circus and theatre (scissors, tape, strings, pieces of cloth, ...)
  • everyday things (shirts, combs, blankets, ...)

Furthermore, the performers have to cover various expenses, including:

  • travelling from camp to camp (truck, gas, ...)
  • equipment for (fire) performing (fuel, extinguishers, ...)
  • equipment for day shows and workshops (clown noses, whistles, batteries...)

We are also going to provide food for the children and their teachers in some of the camps.

Other expenses include paying for water, transportation of children from one camp to another for them to join workshops, medical supplies in case of an emergency, etc.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate you can still help by spreading the word and sharing the campaign in social networks and telling all your friends about it. Make some noise for Spark!Circus 2014! Share the link on Facebook and post it on the timelines of at least ten circus fans. 

If you are broke yet dedicated you can also raise money on street festivals or at fairs, markets and other events.

You can also donate circus tools like juggling balls, hula hoops and more - just contact me!

I highly appreciate any help!

Learn more about the project on sparkcircus.org

story:
Midwifery Volunteering in Tanzania with Gap Medics

My name is Kirsty, and I am 18 years old. I am very passionate about midwifery, and its the only career I would like to pursue. However I have recently been declined from all of my university options on the basis that I don't have enough experience in the field. Therefore after some research I have found an opportunity to go to Tanzania for 2-4 weeks observing and assisting medics and midwives. This will be a great experience and will hopefully allow Universities to see how passionate I am about being a midwife. 
However this opportunity is very costly and so I will have to do quite a lot of fundraising to reach my overall goal of £2500-£3000. I feel that for this price it is an irresistible and amazing experience. 
I would appreciate any funds and donations made towards my cause. It really will benefit me. I would also appreciate it if you could share this around, post it on Facebook, Twitter and any other social network sites as every little helps.
Thank you x

story:
Beacon Academy is committed to providing urban students from Boston with the same opportunities that are afforded to their more affluent peers. One of the starkest educational differences between the two groups is exposure to experiential learning, which enables students to learn from their surroundings rather than just from a textbook. Participating in a mock congress in D.C., visiting an advocacy organization, and touring our nation's most revered monuments provide a transformative experience that simply cannot be accomplished through traditional classroom instruction. It is for that reason that Beacon Academy needs your support to make this opportunity a reality.

Details

Beacon Academy will be partnering with Close Up, a highly regarded organization that specializes in "challenging and hands-on civic, history, and government based educational programs in Washington, DC." Our students will spend four days in D.C. and will, among other activities, debate a domestic issue with policymakers, spend a day on Capitol Hill, and visit the Newseum to explore the ways in which the media has shaped history. 

The Impact

The entire cost of the trip is $1200 per student. When we originally partnered with Close Up, nearly all of the costs were covered through government grants. However, that funding is no longer available and we must raise $20,900 of the $22,800 total. We ask that students raise $250 each, and this idiegogo campaign has been created to support our students with that challenge. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute right now? No problem. We accept donations throughout the year and are grateful for all of the funders who help support our school. We also have several volunteer opportunities throughout the year, including tutoring, coaching, teaching mini-units, and helping with our annual events. If you're interested in volunteering, please reach out to Kinne Chapin (kchapin@beaconacademy.org) to discuss our current opportunities.

story:
Simple People Studios ©


Purpose And Goals For The Future:

Children today are advanced in a way that kids were not even fifteen years ago. Technology is ever changing and so is how our children communicate and socialize with other people, along with that comes different kinds of threats and ways children can be bullied.

The negative and fatal effects of bullying are becoming more evident within our society. With suicides at an all-time high and an increase in violence resulting from bullying, the need for proactive solutions and intervention has risen greatly. Over the years, the face of bullying has changed, as well as the tools and methods used to assist the attacker.


Internet, social media, cell phones, personal handheld devices, and many other electronic tools have enabled the attacker, allowing them to improve the effectiveness of their attacks, without ever facing their victim. Parents, guardians, and school professionals; must become proactive in their efforts to deter those who commit acts of bullying against others.

To address bullying concerns with our own children, a concerned parent drafted an idea for an application for smart phones and a software package for schools. This software would help parents, guardians, teachers, and students to be able to aggressively tackle/reduce bullying. After mentioning the application to peers, an overwhelming interest was shown in the application. After close consideration, a group of information technology professionals with families were selected, to equally take ownership of the idea, and formed Simple People Studios.

What We Will Use Funds For:


We have developed a prototype for an application for smart phones and an overall software package for schools, that will help children and authority figures to capture and record bullying. While we have worked extremely hard to get this idea launched into an actual product, there are some hard costs associated with bringing this application to the market. We humbly ask you to join us in helping launch the Guardian © Bullying Application. The following outlines the project expenses that we would like assistance with:


Initial Development Software Expense

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Server/MS-Apple software development                                     $50,000.00

Android software development                                                        $10,000.00

Apple software development                                                            $10,000.00

State/Federal Bond/Ins.                                                                    $4,000.00

Patenting                                                                                                  $5,000.00

Unforeseen development expenses                                                $10,000.00

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Re-Occurring Software Expense For One Year (software maintenance and upgrades)

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Server/MS-Apple software                                                              $15,000.00     

Android software                                                                                  $5,000.00      

Apple software                                                                                       $5,000.00

Unforeseen maint./upgrade expenses                                          $5,000.00

  


Software Launch Expenses (includes lodging, food, fuel, advertising)

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Unforeseen business expenses                                                      $20,000.00

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Total Project Expenses For One Year  =============>>   $252,264.00                                                 





The team has contributed their own personal resources to further this effort, but we need your help in meeting our other costs to launch this application.


**The following breaks down total team man/work hours per month, since our project launch in October of 2013:

October        2013:                                                                                        556

**The following breaks down other business expenses paid out of pocket, associated with our project since our project launch in October of 2013:

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Total Expenses Maintained Out Of Pocket                                            $3514.00


**The following breaks down re-occurring expenses that are associated with account maintenance, that are paid out of team members pockets:

Company Phone                                                                                     $50.00/mo.

Company Address PO Box                                                                  $12.00/mo.

Fuel Expenses                                                                                          $200.00/mo.

Lodging Expenses                                                                                   $800.00/mo.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Total Expected Re-Occurring Expenses/mo.                                 $1062.00/mo.


Should we exceed our initial goal; the additional money raised will be used to pay toward the balance of the programming and other launch costs along with maintenance fees that acquire over time. 


If we do not reach our goal we will still use the funds to launch and help maintain the Guardian © Bullying Application. We have already researched and spoken to several schools who are very interested in the development of this mitigation application. Our number one goal is to help children and adults in the fight to stop bullying.

As a backer, we will be keeping you informed through email on how the project is doing and what we have accomplished every month.

If you can help financially or not, please help us by getting the word out; 

Please share from the following: Twitter, Facebook, reddit, and email to help us reach our goals.

What Guardian © Bullying Application Will Be Capable Of:


We have developed a prototype for an application for smart phones that will help children and authority figures capture and record bullying. Some of the options we are working on while developing this application are:

-Designed for Personal cellular, handheld, tablet device application/s, and to be compatible with Apple, Android. and Microsoft devices.

-The application will easily activate in a way that will reduce the possibility of being identified by the offender.

-It will provide a user interface for parents/guardians to configure phone numbers and emails.

-It will send emails and text messages to all configured numbers, previously configured by parents/guardians when the application is activated.

- It will activate phones camera/video and audio recording software to record the event when the application is activated.

- Will store the events in the applications database for retrieval by parents/guardians, school officials, law enforcement, etc., in order to identify, discipline, or provide evidence of the event/s.

- Parents/guardians ability to add or edit data related to the offender in the even database.

- Parents/guardians ability to query the events database and/or print reports for tracking of incidents.

- RSS Feed to distract or disguise the activated application. Feed will be selected by parent.

Hope For The Future:


There are many other things we would like to do with Guardian © Bullying Application additional money raised will be put to good use to expand the application and its resources.

Along with the personal device application the goal is to develop a School/District Software Package program that will work along with the personal device application. It will be compatible with Microsoft, Android, and Apple devices:

- This package would be developed for and purchased by individual school districts.

- Client applications would be developed for student workstations, school and student owned mobile or handheld devices, including iPods, iPads, Microsoft, and Android devices.

- Server application would be developed and work in cooperation with present architecture.

- All client devices would perform same or similar tasks as in personal device application, but would also inject the data into server database metrics, resolution, and data mining by stat and local agencies. All state and federal compliance must be met.

A Little About The Team:


Each member of this team has invested extensive time and financials towards their education, and all hold a diverse range of skills and degrees. At no time will the skills of any member of this team be in question. All are viewed as professionals in their field, which we believe is an asset that we will present to each client.



Team members:

Darren Jeter- Project Mgr.

AAS Information Systems/Network Administration
BS Information Systems Security/Digital Forensics
MS Information Systems/Project Management



Jodi Jeter - Client Communications 

Cert. Business Strategies/Management , Iowa Insurance Lic.





Bobby Dineen - Programmer/Analyst

Masters Degree Information Systems

Emphasis in Database Management/Design Networking

Bachelors Computer Science

Minor in Math/Minor Network Security


 

Gene Arch - Programmer/Analyst

BS Computer Graphics and Animation

MS in Information Systems

 

 

 

Joe Russell - Project Lead

Diploma in Computer Science



Megan Russell - Fundraising Sales Consultant

BA Registered Nursing




James Manns - Project Lead

AAS Computer Science

A+ Cert., Network + Cert., MCSE, Net Admin




Brian Wallace - Project Lead 

Human Resources/Business Management



Kim Wallace - Marketing and Public Relations




Matthew Schroeder - Systems Analyst

AAS Computer Programming

AAS Network Administration

A+ Certification, Network+ Certification




Andrea Hannu - Project Specialist

AAS Computer Science

 


Dylan Moore - Social Media Director

Presently Enrolled: Computer Science/Engineering




Beatrice Cooper - Treasurer

Radiology Pre-authorization Specialist
Certified NA
Beta Tester, public relations assistant for senior partner InWorldz IBM 3D graphic artist adviser/Assistant Second Life Project Assistant for Burning Man Second Life
Bank Mgr





All team members that are a part of Simple People Studios © have been selected to be a part of the team, because they have goals that are in line with each of us. We feel as though all members reflect the same ethical, social, and professional images; that we are proud to present to our clients and the public. We all are striving to develop and help improve the ideas that have been set forth.

This software would help parents, guardians, teachers, and students to be able to aggressively tackle/reduce bullying. After mentioning the application to peers, an overwhelming interest was shown in the application. After close consideration, a group of information technology professionals with families were selected, to equally take ownership of the idea, and formed Simple People Studios.
 

What We Will Use Funds For: 
We have developed a prototype for an application for smart phones and an overall software package for schools, that will help children and authority figures to capture and record bullying. While we have worked extremely hard to get this idea launched into an actual product, there are some hard costs associated with bringing this application to the market. We humbly ask you to join us in helping launch the Guardian © Bullying Application. The following outlines the project expenses that we would like assistance with:

Should we exceed our initial goal; the additional money raised will be
used to pay toward the balance of the programming and other launch costs along with maintenance fees that acquire over time. 
If we do not reach our goal we will still use the funds to launch and
help maintain the Guardian © Bullying Application. We have already researched and spoken to several
schools who are very interested in the development of this mitigation application. Our
number one goal is to help children and adults in the fight to stop bullying.As a backer, we will be keeping you informed through email on how the project is doing and what we have accomplished every month.If you can help financially or not, please help us by getting
the word out; 
Please share from the following: Twitter, Facebook, reddit, and email to help us reach our goals.What
Guardian © Bullying Application Will Be
Capable Of:



We have
developed a prototype for an application for smart phones that will
help children and authority figures capture and record bullying. Some of
the options we are working on while developing this application are:

-Designed
for Personal cellular, handheld, tablet device application/s,
and to be
compatible with Apple, Android. and Microsoft
devices.-The
application will easily activate in a way that will reduce
the possibility of being identified by the offender.

-It
will provide a user interface for parents/guardians to configure
phone numbers and emails.-It
will send emails and text messages to all configured numbers,
previously configured by parents/guardians when the
application is activated.-
It will activate phones camera/video and audio recording software to record the event when the application is
activated. -
Will store the events in the applications database for
retrieval by parents/guardians, school officials,
law enforcement, etc., in order to identify, discipline, or provide evidence
of the event/s.-
Parents/guardians ability to add or edit data related to the offender in the even database.-
Parents/guardians ability to query the events database and/or print reports for tracking of incidents.-
RSS Feed to distract or disguise the activated application. Feed will be selected by parent.
 
Hope For The Future:



There are many other things we would like to do with Guardian © Bullying Application additional money raised will be put to good use to expand the application and its resources.Along with the personal device application the goal is to develop a School/District Software Package program that will work along
with the personal device application. It will be compatible with Microsoft,
Android, and Apple devices:- This package would be developed for and purchased by individual school districts.- Client applications would be developed for student workstations, school and student owned mobile or
handheld devices, including iPods, iPads, Microsoft, and Android devices.
- Server application would be developed and work in cooperation with present architecture.- All client devices would perform same or similar tasks as in personal device application, but would also inject the data into server database metrics, resolution, and data mining by stat and local agencies. All state and federal compliance must be met.

Each member of this team has invested extensive time and financials towards their education, and all hold a diverse range of
skills and degrees. At no time will the skills of any member of this team be in
question. All are viewed as professionals in their field, which we believe is
an asset that we will present to each client.

story:
Hello All!

My name is Alexandra Reid and I am currently a freshman at Baylor University. I am majoring in Elementary Education with an emphasis on Special Education.

For years now I have felt God calling me to serve in the nations but I have never been able to pinpoint an exact location. I have always known I wanted to serve in Africa but I could never decide on a specific village, city, or even a location. My mom has always told me "If God wants you to go on a mission trip, He will tell you. He will open all of the doors and you will without a doubt know that He is calling you to go. You will not have to look for a trip because God will show you where He wants you." I have constantly been repeating this to myself for the past three years as I have been patiently waiting for a sign from God that this is what He has in store for me. Finally, at the beginning of my 2014 spring semester at Baylor, an organization called Buckner International came and told us about different mission opportunities they offered during the summer. After hearing everything Buckner had to offer I knew this was exactly what I had been waiting for for so many years. I decided to apply into the program. I knew if I was accepted into the program that my mission plans would soon start to move full speed ahead but if I didn't get in, this was God's way of telling me that this was not what He had in store for me right now. I would be ok with either answer God had for me. After a long interview process and weeks of waiting, praying, and biting my nails I had my answer. On Friday, February 21 I was informed that I had been accepted into Buckner International for Project Go! On July 7, 2014 I will officially be flying to Addis Ababa, Ethiopia to begin this exciting and life changing journey God has in store for me. Not only will I get to spend my time in Ethiopia spreading the word of God but I will get to spend my time with the humblest of individuals. I get to share the word of God to the broken and the hurt and show them the abounding love that their Father has for them. While in Ethiopia, I will be assisting in social work home visits, teaching my own classes of english and reading to elementary schoolers along with any other subject, assisting other teachers, teaching a Bible class, leading recreation and Bible studies and helping in the clinic. I will be in Ethiopia from July 7 through August 7. 

God has provided me with this wonderful journey to share His love and grace to the people of Addis Ababa, Ethiopia and I am beyond blessed to have gotten this opportunity. While I am fully confident that God will provide a way for me to raise the funds in order to go on this trip, I need all the help I can get. I would also appreciate any prayers and encouragement along the way. This is a new and exciting journey for me but I give all the credit and thanks to God because it is because of Him that I am going on this trip. The Lord is my sole purpose for going on this trip. I want to be able to share His word with as many people as I possibly can while in Ethiopia. My goal is to show them that God's love is the greatest love they could ever hope to find. Most importantly I want to be able to show them not only through my own life but throughout their life as well that they too can have a Heavenly Father who is always there for them and a King who encourages and loves them more than they could ever imagine. 

Thank you so much for your prayers and donations! God bless!

story:
HIGH SCHOOL

...two words that conjure up more memories than you can count. It's four years of hard work and add an extra curricular activity to the mix and you have a very busy student. But if you're lucky, and your child becomes part of a program whose members, director and parent volunteers are as committed, hard-working, and dedicated to the success of that program as we are as Band Boosters of Holly Springs High School in Holly Springs, NC, then your student also has a lot of FUN! 

THE Holly Springs High School
  Golden Hawks Regiment

What has 230 legs but is not going anywhere? 
Our band program if we don't get 2 new trucks!! 

Up 20% from 2013 to 2014, our band program has grown to 160 members of which 115 are GHR marching members. This is a blessing and a curse if you can't keep up with your needs.  We have outgrown our truck space and transportation to events and competitions is now a very real challenge. The band programs in our school system receive limited funding every seven years to help with expenses. Last year we received $18K with which we purchased 3 instruments. All other costs of our $60K annual budget (uniforms, band camp meals, transportation, music, instructors, competition fees, etc) come from the parents (aka Band Boosters) and through fundraising year after year. We are fortunate to live in a community of people who are willing to provide the resources through donations and support that we rely on and of which we are so appreciative. But we now have a problem whose solution is beyond the scope of local fundraising and we need help.

Practice makes perfect....


If you were never in band in high school, and I was not, you probably are not aware of the amount of hours student musicians spend practicing. Our band camp (insert snicker here..."one time, at band camp...") starts July 30 and includes 12-hour days for 3 weeks before school starts. And they love it~

   

  


Truck-a-GoGo

The funds raised through this campaign will go specifically to the purchase of two 26-foot 'box' trucks, like a moving truck, to transport our instruments, uniforms, and props to competitions and performances. Our current truck is unreliable (and now too small) and our dads have been keeping it limping along, but eventually the time will come when the kids will be at competition and their instruments will not. 

Having met with a local dealership, and through research, we are looking at a cost of approximately $80K for each truck.  We're not opposed to used vehicles, but we have learned that trucks this size typically have high mileage on them already as they are moving trucks, and we'd likely be in the same situation in the near future with the purchase of used. Also, a 26-foot long truck is the largest we can drive without a commercial license. 

Additional funding above and beyond our goal will go to the general fund for the band to pay for the expenses mentioned earlier - like more instruments and competition costs. If we don't reach our goal, we will still earmark all donations for our truck fund, first and foremost. 

           

By helping us reach our goal, you'll be:

  • helping to keep the ARTS alive in our schools
  • teaching our students the benefits and rewards of working together
  • allowing our students to experience being a part of something bigger than themselves
  • encouraging hard work and dedication (did I mention 12-hour days at band camp for 3 weeks before school starts?) 
  • promoting team work  - winning and losing together

We need you!...and everyone you know. 

Even if you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help. Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Use the Indiegogo share tools to post, tweet and send our campaign to everyone you know. All donations are tax deductible! 

         

ABOUT US...

Since 2006, THE  Holly Springs High School Band has been able to achieve great success with our award winning Golden Hawks Band Program. Our Band Program is made up of several groups including the award-winning Golden Hawks Regiment (marching band), three concert bands, high school, middle school, and elementary school winter guards, indoor percussion, jazz ensemble and several chamber ensembles.

And after all of the practice, frustration, 12-hour days, weekends, sweat, sunburn, wet feet, and bug bites....this is what you get! 

*****AWARDS*****

2014-03-29 Atlantic Indoor Association Championships

Wakefield High School and Dorton Arena - Raleigh, NC

Congratulations to our winterguard programs for their fine season on the Atlantic Indoor Association circuit. Our band program sponsors the Lil' Hawks (elementary), Junior Hawks (middle), and Hawks (high). The Lil' Hawks won the GOLD medal at the circuit championships on March 29, in the elementary division. The Hawks won the SILVER medal at the same championships in the high school division Regional A2 class.

2014-03-24 & 03-26 Central District Music Performance Adjudication

Franklinton High School - Franklinton, NC

Wind Ensemble received an EXCELLENT rating in level VI at the Music Performance Adjudication at Franklinton HS. They received a Superior in Sight-Reading.

Symphonic Band received a SUPERIOR rating in level IV at the Music Performance Adjudication at Franklinton HS. They also received a Superior in Sight-Reading. The Symphonic Band earned this in their first year participating at MPA.

We're very proud of their accomplishment. This marks the 8th time in school history that an HSHS Band has received a Superior Rating at a MPA event.

2014-03-08 All-State Honor's Band East Davidson High School

Thomasville, NC

Congratulations to David Eastley, who earned the 4th chair seat in the North Carolina All-State 11/12 Honor's Band on horn. He performed in concert at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill on Sunday, May 4. This marks the 8th straight year that Holly Springs High School has had a representative in an All-State Band. He is only the 5th student to ever achieve All-State status in our eight year history.

2014-02-21 NC Bandmasters Association Central All-District Bands

Congratulations to the following individuals who represented Holly Springs High School at the 2014 North Carolina Bandmasters Association Central All-District Bands. The event was held February 21-22 at Asheboro High School. We had eight members selected this year, the most in school history. The 11/12 Wind Ensemble was under the direction of Dr. John LaCognata, Director of Bands at the University of North Carolina at Wilmington. The 9-12 Symphonic Band was under the direction of Mr. Tom Jenner, 2012 Central District Award of Excellence Winner and Band Director at Wendell Middle School.

David Eastley - 3rd Chair Horn - 11/12 Wind Ensemble
Andy Brooks - 3rd Chair Snare - 11/12 Wind Ensemble
Jamin Coleman - 4th Chair Snare - 11/12 Wind Ensemble
Ryan Wing - 1st Chair Clarinet - 9-12 Symphonic Band
Othmane Jadi - 9th Chair Clarinet - 9-12 Symphonic Band
Mary Gaughan - 7th Chair Trumpet - 9-12 Symphonic Band
Tyler Stephenson - 12th Chair Trumpet - 9-12 Symphonic Band
Matt Brooks - 2nd Chair Mallets - 9-12 Symphonic Band

2013-10-19 Central District Marching Band MPA

Central District Marching Band Music Performance Adjudication was held at Fuquay-Varina HS.

The Golden Hawks Regiment became the 1st marching band from the Central District to earn an overall SUPERIOR rating.

2013-10-19 Fuquay-Varina Festival of Bands

The 25th Annual Fuquay-Varina Festival of Bands was held in Fuquay-Varina, NC

  • AAA 4th Place (7th overall/17 bands) - 88.9 
  • AAA 3rd Place Music Individual 
  • AAA 5th Place Music Ensemble 
  • AAA 3rd Place Tie Music Effect 
  • AAA 4th Place Visual Performance 
  • AAA 3rd Place Visual Effect
  • AAA 1st Place Percussion - SUPERIOR (3rd highest score of the day)
  • AAA 2nd Place Guard (3rd highest score of the day)
  • Drum Major Caption not awarded

2013-10-12 West Johnston Invitational

The 10th Annual West Johnston Invitational was held in Benson, NC.

  • AAA 4th Place (7th Overall/25 Bands) - 88.3 
  • AAA 2nd Place Music Individual 
  • AAA 2nd Place Music Ensemble 
  • AAA 4th Place Music Effect 
  • AAA 2nd Place Tie Visual Performance 
  • AAA 5th Place Visual Effect 
  • AAA 1st Place Percussion -
  • AAA 3rd Place Drum Major 
  • AAA Guard - EXCELLENT

2013-09-28 Cleveland Critique and Competition

The 3rd Annual Cleveland Critique and Competition was held in Clayton, NC.

  • AAAA 4th Place (5th Overall/16 Bands) - 86.5 
  • AAAA 3rd Place Tie Music Individual 
  • AAAA 4th Place Music Ensemble 
  • AAAA 4th Place Music Effect 
  • AAAA 4th Place Visual Performance 
  • AAAA 4th Place Visual Effect 
  • AAAA 4th Place Percussion 
  • AAAA 4th Place Guard 
  • Drum Major Awarded not awarded. 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!


GO HAWKS!!

Our band camp (insert snicker here..."one time, at band camp...") starts July 30 and includes 12-hour days for 3 weeks before school starts. And they love it~

   



  


Truck-a-GoGo
 The funds raised through this campaign will go specifically to the purchase of two 26-foot 'box' trucks, like a moving truck, to transport our instruments, uniforms, and props to competitions and performances. Our current truck is unreliable (and now too small) and our dads have been keeping it limping along, but eventually the time will come when the kids will be at competition and their instruments will not. 
Having met with a local dealership, and through research, we are looking at a cost of approximately $80K for each truck.  We're not opposed to used vehicles, but we have learned that trucks this size typically have high mileage on them already as they are moving trucks, and we'd likely be in the same situation in the near future with the purchase of used. Also, a 26-foot long truck is the largest we can drive without a commercial license. 
Additional funding above and beyond our goal will go to the general fund for the band to pay for the expenses mentioned earlier - like more instruments and competition costs. If we don't reach our goal, we will still earmark all donations for our truck fund, first and foremost. 


           


By helping us reach our goal, you'll be:



helping to keep the ARTS alive in our schools
teaching our students the benefits and rewards of working together
allowing our students to experience being a part of something bigger than themselves
encouraging hard work and dedication (did I mention 12-hour days at band camp for 3 weeks before school starts?) 
promoting team work  - winning and losing together 





We need you!...and everyone you know. 

 Even if you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help. Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Use the Indiegogo share tools to post, tweet and send our campaign to everyone you know. All donations are tax deductible! 

         

ABOUT US...Since 2006, THE  Holly Springs High School Band has been able to achieve great success with our award winning Golden Hawks Band Program. Our Band Program is made up of several groups including the award-winning Golden Hawks Regiment (marching band), three concert bands, high school, middle school, and elementary school winter guards, indoor percussion, jazz ensemble and several chamber ensembles.

And after all of the practice, frustration, 12-hour days, weekends, sweat, sunburn, wet feet, and bug bites....this is what you get! 



*****AWARDS*****
2014-03-29 Atlantic Indoor Association Championships
Wakefield High School and Dorton Arena - Raleigh, NC 

Congratulations to our winterguard programs for their fine season on the 
Atlantic Indoor Association circuit. Our band program sponsors the Lil' Hawks 
(elementary), Junior Hawks (middle), and Hawks (high). The Lil' Hawks won the 
GOLD medal at the circuit championships on March 29, in the elementary division. 
The Hawks won the SILVER medal at the same championships in the high school 
division Regional A2 class. 

2014-03-24 & 03-26 Central District Music Performance Adjudication
Franklinton High School - Franklinton, NC 

Wind Ensemble received an EXCELLENT rating in level VI at the Music 
Performance Adjudication at Franklinton HS. They received a Superior in 
Sight-Reading. 

Symphonic Band received a SUPERIOR rating in level IV at the Music 
Performance Adjudication at Franklinton HS. They also received a Superior in 
Sight-Reading. The Symphonic Band earned this in their first year participating 
at MPA. 

We're very proud of their accomplishment. This marks the 8th time in school 
history that an HSHS Band has received a Superior Rating at a MPA event. 

2014-03-08 All-State Honor's Band East Davidson High School
Thomasville, NC 

Congratulations to David Eastley, who earned the 4th chair seat in the North 
Carolina All-State 11/12 Honor's Band on horn. He performed in concert at the 
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill on Sunday, May 4. This marks the 8th 
straight year that Holly Springs High School has had a representative in an 
All-State Band. He is only the 5th student to ever achieve All-State status in 
our eight year history. 

2014-02-21 NC Bandmasters Association Central All-District Bands
Congratulations to the following individuals who represented Holly Springs 
High School at the 2014 North Carolina Bandmasters Association 
Central All-District Bands. The event was held February 21-22 at Asheboro High 
School. We had eight members selected this year, the most in school history. The 
11/12 Wind Ensemble was under the direction of Dr. John LaCognata, Director of 
Bands at the University of North Carolina at Wilmington. The 9-12 Symphonic Band 
was under the direction of Mr. Tom Jenner, 2012 Central District Award of 
Excellence Winner and Band Director at Wendell Middle School.

story:
Who Is Sociopreneur Indonesia (SociopreneurID)?

Since 2013, SociopreneurlD has been promoting social entrepreneurship spirit to Indonesians through various programs. For the last five years, our own works have been driven by human interests and we found there is a need to change perception and improve creativity skills in order to be agile in this complex world. By promoting empathy through science, creativity, and innovation, we believe we can encourage various stakeholders including society to work together tackling various issues around them as a manifestation of collective—responsibility.

Recently, SociopreneurID has become one of examples at CIVICUS Youth Participation Platform on how to reach the youth by creating diverse programs, so they have various opportunities to participate in making positive impact to society and planet, find out more on: http://www.civicus.org/youth_engagement_toolkit/reaching-youth/

SociopreneurID Described in Numbers

Our journey for the last five years has helped to create 22.000 learners, 800 volunteers, 950+ solutions created, 400 collaborators, and 5000 books & educational tools donated. It is indeed a wonderful journey and through the community supports we are motivated to keep the spirit for years and years to come! But we realize we can't do this alone. That's why we developed a multi-stakeholders ecosystem in which every stakeholder takes responsibility to improve human quality.

What will be in Empathy Project 2019?

This year, Empathy Project 2019 will deliver four programs, as below:

1. Young Entrepreneurs Camp (YOURS Camp)

YOURS Camp aims to improve participants' entrepreneurial skills through intensive experiential learning that enables them to learn to design, develop, and deliver relevant solutions based on defined context. Yours Camp will be conducted from July 12th - 17th 2019 and is open for local and international participants. 

YOURS Camp is our partially funded program, so participants only will cover their living expenses that will  cover their accommodation, local transport, and meals. All learning materials, camp kits, practical works, and mentorship will be covered by SociopreneurID.

Furthermore, if the particpants decide to attend MSD and FeSoVity, all accommodation, local transport and meals will be borne by SociopreneurID.

2. Bootcamp for Young Technopreneur (BYTe)

Bootcamp for Young Technopreneur (BYTe) is a program that aims to improve participants' innovation skill through intensive experiential learning by solving real life problems. It is focusing on Developing Responsible Ecosystem through Creative Economy where selected recipients will learn to identify and develop solutions based on real-life problems in SMEs around South Tangerang based on Design Thinking and Design Ethnography method. Recipients will immerse and experience SMEs firsthand. BYTe is open only for Indonesian nationals and we provide full scholarship program for selected participants.

This program will be conducted from July 14th - 17th 2019.

3. Multi-Stakeholder Dialogue (MSD)

Multi-Stakeholder Dialogue (MSD) is a platform to connect ABGS (Academia, Business, Government, and Society) to develop collaborative actions. This program aims to emerge collaborations and discover solutions for various challenges. Different present entities are expected to exchange ideas and knowledge, weave networks, and co-create solutions for different problems before implementing it together.

MSD will be conducted from July 18th - 19th 2019 and is open for international and national participants.

4. Festival of Social Creativity (FeSoVity)

Running July 19th-20th focusing on Developing Responsible Ecosystem through Upcycling will involve around 1,500 people consisting of 1,000 primary and secondary students, 150 teachers and parents, 100 volunteers, 200 society and community members, and 50 committee members. Different present entities will play, express themselves, and create educative media from used resources as to upcycle them into useful and usable products. The products will then be donated to marginal schools in need. FeSoVity will be concluded with Impact Run and Micro-Library establishment.

 

How to Support Empathy Project 2019?

1. Join the army of #Earthvenger!

The theme of incoming Empathy Project (EP) is Developing Responsible Ecosystem to Protect the Earth, with a special highlight to environmental and ecological issues. In a simplified way, this means that every individual is expected to understand and be aware of the problems around them and actively find solutions to solve them. Therefore, in proceeding to the event, we are holding a campaign to emphasize how every individual has the power in protecting the Earth. We invite you to participate in this campaign. Help us to widespread this message! You can find more of our campaign through our Facebook page, or other media by searching #Earthvenger and #ProtectEarth.

 

2. Support our crowdfunding campaign​

Empathy Project 2019 needs to raise $5000. These funds will be allocated to support FeSoVity of which are:

1. 1000 literacy package about environment (we attach the book cover of 'Anak Rimba', an environmental book for children, below)

You can find out more about 'Anak Rimba' here:

Anak Rimba Video
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fA-_BPCedVM

Website
www.anak-rimba.com

YOUTUBE Channel
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCXkfsodL0teua4...

Facebook & Instagram
https://www.facebook.com/anakrimbabooks
https://www.instagram.com/anakrimbabooks/

UN Sustainable Development Goal Action Awards submission
https://sdgactionawards.org/initiative/1444

 

2. 1000 educational games to improve creativity

3. 1000 additional materials for creating upcycling products


4. Establishing 3 micro-libraries

We are working so hard to meet our goal, but we really can’t do it without you! We are hoping that you would make a contribution and share our stories to as many people as you can to help us accomplish the goal. We'll make sure to send you the updates from our proceeding Empathy Project 2019!

story:
[für Deutsch nach unten scrollen]

[magyar szöveg az oldal alján]

EN 

The kind donations of our numerous supporters have helped us to complete the ground floor and the walls of the first floor of the school building during the summer holidays in 2016 and 2017. These four semi-finished classrooms are already in use, providing already better study environment for the 240 students of Newill Academy. We have also harvested and treated bamboo to be used on the facade.

This year during the school holiday in August we are planning to complete the first floor including three classrooms and the library and build the walls of the four classrooms on the last floor.

Your donations will all go towards the development of Newill Academy, buying building materials and covering the salary of the local workers. Most of the work is to be done by our volunteers. Be the part of the change! You can choose to support us anonymously but we would be glad to reward your generosity and keep in touch with you if you choose one of the available perks.

The story of Newill Academy started in 2010 when Mr. William Newman, a Ghanaian teacher founded a nursery in an empty storage building next to his mother's house in Koforidua. His aim is to provide quality daycare and education for children who suffer social disadvantage in the area, mainly the children of the market sellers and street vendors who can't afford to stay at home with them. As the children grew, the academy grew together with them, starting primary classes. The school works on a non-profit basis, the students pay a minimal fee which just covers the teacher's salary, transportation by the school bus and one meal per day.

Although the founder and headmaster of the school along with the board of teachers are working hard to provide their best for the pupils, in lack of proper financial background the academy is facing various challenges. First of all, it is overcrowded, the infrastructure is not sufficient enough for the amount of students. The children are keen on studying but instead of classrooms they are staying in temporary shelter-like structures exposed to the various weather conditions. Sanitary facilities also need improvement.

A group of European architects in close cooperation with the local management have revised the plans in 2016 and started the construction works of the low-cost sustainable school building during the summer holidays of 2016 and 2017.

In order to keep building costs and future maintenance low, locally available materials, handmade structures, passive ventilation and a rainwater harvesting system are included. The bricks are handmade, produced on site by volunteers. Interior elements and parts of the facade are made of bamboo, harvested in the nearby forest. The elevated roof functions as a solar chimney, creating natural air movement when warmed up by the sun.

The project was awarded by the Media Architecture Prize 2016, one of the most significant prizes of contemporary architecture in Hungary.

 

design team:

  Bogdan Funk

  Balazs Szelecsenyi

  Orsolya Vadasz

  Dia Nusszer

  Csinszka Cserhati

building structures:

  Daniel Veto

sustainable systems:

  Roland Nemeth (www.tectobio.com)

visualization:

  Gabor Gyenese (www.gyga.ch)

video:

  Lilla Vaczi

 

DE

Die grosszügigen Spenden unserer zahlreichen Unterstützer halfen uns, das Erdgeschoss sowie die Wände des ersten Stockwerks an der Newill Academy während den Sommerferien im August 2016 und 2017 aufzubauen. Die Räume werden im aktuellen Rohzustand bereits genutzt und bieten ein besseres Umfeld für den Unterricht der 240 Schüler. Zudem konnten wir Bambus gewinnen und als Verkleidung für die Fassade vorbereiten.

Im August 2018 ist die Fertigstellung des ersten Stockwerks mit den drei Klassenzimmern und dem Bibliotheksraum sowie der Aufbau der Wände des zweiten Obergeschosses geplant.

Ihre freundlichen Spenden werden alle auf die Entwicklung der Newill Academy gehen, um Baustoffe zu kaufen und die Kosten der örtlichen Mitrbeiter abzudecken. Die meisten Arbeiten sind von unseren Freiwilligen zu erledigen. Sei der Teil der Veränderung! Sie können wählen, um uns anonym zu unterstützen, wir würden uns aber freuen, Ihre Großzügigkeit zu belohnen und in Kontakt zu bleiben, wenn Sie eine der verfügbaren Vergünstigungen wählen.

Die Geschichte der Newill Academy begann im Jahr 2010, als Herr William Newman, ein ghanaischer Lehrer einen Kindergarten in einem leeren Lagerhaus neben dem Haus seiner Mutter in Koforidua gründete. Sein Ziel ist es, qualitativ hochwertige Kindertagesstätten und Schulung für bedürftigte Kinder in der Region, vor allem die Kinder der Marktverkäufer und Straßenverkäufer, die nicht leisten können, zu Hause bleiben mit ihnen zu bleiben. Als die Kinder wuchsen, wuchs die Akademie zusammen mit ihnen, und primäre Klassen wurden gestartet. Die Schule arbeitet auf einer gemeinnützigen Basis, die Studenten zahlen eine minimale Gebühr, die nur das Lehrergehalt, den Transport durch den Schulbus und eine Mahlzeit pro Tag abdeckt.

Obwohl der Gründer und Schulleiter der Schule zusammen mit der Lehrkräfte hart daran arbeiten, das Beste für die Schüler zu geben, liegt die Akademie im Mangel an ordnungsgemäßem finanziellen Hintergrund vor verschiedenen Herausforderungen. Zuerst ist es überfüllt, die Infrastruktur reicht für die Anzahl der Schüler nicht aus. Die Kinder sind begeistert auf das Studium, aber anstatt der Klassenzimmer bleiben sie in temporären, schutzähnlichen Strukturen, die den verschiedenen Wetterbedingungen ausgesetzt sind. Sanitäranlagen müssen ebenfalls verbessert werden.

Eine Gruppe europäischer Architekten hat in enger Zusammenarbeit mit dem örtlichen Management die Pläne im Jahr 2016 überarbeitet und im Sommer 2016 mit den Bauarbeiten des kostengünstigen, nachhaltigen Schulgebäudes angefangen. In den nächsten Jahren sollen zwei weitere Bauphasen folgen, um die Akademie abzuschließen der komfortablen und passenden Platz für die 240 Schüler bietet.

Um Baukosten und zukünftige Instandhaltung niedrig zu halten, sind lokal verfügbare Materialien, handgefertigte Strukturen, passive Lüftung und ein Regenwassernutzungsanlage enthalten. Die Ziegel sind handgefertigt, produziert vor Ort von Freiwilligen. Innenelemente und Teile der Fassade sind aus Bambus gefertigt, im nahe gelegenen Wald gesammelt. Das erhöhte Dach dientsolar chimney als Solarkamin und erzeugt so eine natürliche Luftbewegung, wenn er von der Sonne aufgewärmt wird.

Das Projekt wurde vom Medienarchitekturpreis 2016 verliehen, einer der bedeutendsten Preise zeitgenössischer von Architektur in Ungarn. 

 

Design:

  Bogdan Funk

  Balazs Szelecsenyi

  Orsolya Vadasz

  Dia Nusszer

  Csinszka Cserhati

Bauingenieur:

  Daniel Veto

Nachhaltige Systeme:

  Roland Nemeth (www.tectobio.com)

Visualisierung:

  Gabor Gyenese (www.gyga.ch)

Video:

  Lilla Vaczi

 

HU

Számos támogatónk nagylelkű adományának köszönhetően 2016 és 2017 nyarán felépíthettük a Newill Academy új iskolaépületének földszintjét és megkezdhettük az első emeleti falak építését. Ezek a szerkezetkész helyiségek már használatban vannak, megkönnyítve a 240 diák mindennapjait.  Gyűjtöttünk továbbá bambuszt melyet előkészítettünk a homlokzaton való felhasználásra.

Idén az augusztusi tanítási szünetben az első emeleti három tanterem és könyvtárhelyiség befejezését tervezzük, valamint a legfelső szint falainak felállítását.

A beérkezett adományokat teljes egészében a Newill Academy fejlesztésére fordítjuk, elsősorban építőanyagok vásárlására és a helyi munkaerő bérének fedezésére. A munka javát önkéntesekből álló csapatunk fogja elvégezni. Légy te is a változás részese! Támogathatsz minket név nélkül is, de örömmel könszönetet mondanánk nagylelkűségedért amennyiben az alábbi opciók közül választasz és megadod elérhetőséged.

A Newill Akadémia története 2010-ben kezdődött, amikor William Newman, egy helyi tanár az édesanyja koforiduai háza melletti üres melléképületben egy szociális alapon működő óvodát és általános iskolát indított. Az intézmény hiánypótló, hiszen a városban nem, illetve csak nagyon drágán áll rendelkezésre hasonló ellátás, a hátrányosabb helyzetű szülők a mindennapi megélhetés előteremtésével vannak elfoglalva, nem tudnak családjukkal otthon maradni. Az intézmény aztán az évek során a gyerekekkel együtt nőtt, és hamarosan általános iskolai osztályok is indultak.

Az évek alatt az iskola kinőtte az eredeti épületet, mára több osztály terem híján folyosókon vagy az udvaron felállított egyszerű tető alatt tanul. Már évekkel ezelőtt tervek készültek az iskola fejlesztésére, megfelelő anyagi háttér hiányában azonban csak egy új épülettömb alapozása és lábazata készült el.

Ekkor magyar építészek egy lelkes csoportja a helyi vezetéssel együttműködve és a fenntarthatóságot valamint a klimatikus viszonyokat szem előtt tartva továbbfejlesztették a terveket. Az eredeti tervekből megmaradt a 3 szintes épület és az L alakú alaprajz, optimalizálva lett viszont a nyílásosztás, a közlekedés rendszere, továbbá közösségi terek kerültek kialakításra és az udvarral való kapcsolat is át lett fogalmazva. Trópusi éghajlaton a legfontosabb tervezési szempont az árnyékolás és szellőzés biztosítása, ezt mélyen ülő lamellás ablakokkal, nagy tetőkinyúlással, az osztálytermek perforált falaival valamint a folyosó felőli oldalon hézagos bambusz homlokzati burkolattal igyekeztünk elérni. A zárófödémtől elemelt fémlemez tető hamar felmelegszik ezért napkéményként tud működni, a felszálló meleg levegő elvét kihasználva biztosítja a tantermek természetes szellőzését.

A projekt 2016-ban elnyerte a média Építészeti Díja közönségdíját, mely a kortárs építészet egyik legjelentősebb elismerése Magyarországon.

  Bogdan Funk

  Balazs Szelecsenyi

  Orsolya Vadasz

látvány:

  Gabor Gyenese (www.gyga.ch)

  Lilla Vaczi
story_txt:
[für Deutsch nach unten scrollen]
[magyar szöveg az oldal alján]
EN 
The kind donations of our numerous supporters have helped us to complete the ground floor and the walls of the first floor of the school building during the summer holidays in 2016 and 2017. These four semi-finished classrooms are already in use, providing already better study environment for the 240 students of Newill Academy. We have also harvested and treated bamboo to be used on the facade.

This year during the school holiday in August we are planning to complete the first floor including three classrooms and the library and build the walls of the four classrooms on the last floor.
Your donations will all go towards the development of Newill Academy, buying building materials and covering the salary of the local workers. Most of the work is to be done by our volunteers. Be the part of the change! You can choose to support us anonymously but we would be glad to reward your generosity and keep in touch with you if you choose one of the available perks.

The story of Newill Academy started in 2010 when Mr. William Newman, a Ghanaian teacher founded a nursery in an empty storage building next to his mother's house in Koforidua. His aim is to provide quality daycare and education for children who suffer social disadvantage in the area, mainly the children of the market sellers and street vendors who can't afford to stay at home with them. As the children grew, the academy grew together with them, starting primary classes. The school works on a non-profit basis, the students pay a minimal fee which just covers the teacher's salary, transportation by the school bus and one meal per day.
Although the founder and headmaster of the school along with the board of teachers are working hard to provide their best for the pupils, in lack of proper financial background the academy is facing various challenges. First of all, it is overcrowded, the infrastructure is not sufficient enough for the amount of students. The children are keen on studying but instead of classrooms they are staying in temporary shelter-like structures exposed to the various weather conditions. Sanitary facilities also need improvement.
A group of European architects in close cooperation with the local management have revised the plans in 2016 and started the construction works of the low-cost sustainable school building during the summer holidays of 2016 and 2017.

In order to keep building costs and future maintenance low, locally available materials, handmade structures, passive ventilation and a rainwater harvesting system are included. The bricks are handmade, produced on site by volunteers. Interior elements and parts of the facade are made of bamboo, harvested in the nearby forest. The elevated roof functions as a solar chimney, creating natural air movement when warmed up by the sun.
The project was awarded by the Media Architecture Prize 2016, one of the most significant prizes of contemporary architecture in Hungary.
 
design team:
  Bogdan Funk
  Balazs Szelecsenyi
  Orsolya Vadasz
  Dia Nusszer
  Csinszka Cserhati
building structures:
  Daniel Veto
sustainable systems:
  Roland Nemeth (www.tectobio.com)
visualization:
  Gabor Gyenese (www.gyga.ch)
video:
  Lilla Vaczi
 
DE
Die grosszügigen Spenden unserer zahlreichen Unterstützer halfen uns, das Erdgeschoss sowie die Wände des ersten Stockwerks an der Newill Academy während den Sommerferien im August 2016 und 2017 aufzubauen. Die Räume werden im aktuellen Rohzustand bereits genutzt und bieten ein besseres Umfeld für den Unterricht der 240 Schüler. Zudem konnten wir Bambus gewinnen und als Verkleidung für die Fassade vorbereiten.
Im August 2018 ist die Fertigstellung des ersten Stockwerks mit den drei Klassenzimmern und dem Bibliotheksraum sowie der Aufbau der Wände des zweiten Obergeschosses geplant.
Ihre freundlichen Spenden werden alle auf die Entwicklung der Newill Academy gehen, um Baustoffe zu kaufen und die Kosten der örtlichen Mitrbeiter abzudecken. Die meisten Arbeiten sind von unseren Freiwilligen zu erledigen. Sei der Teil der Veränderung! Sie können wählen, um uns anonym zu unterstützen, wir würden uns aber freuen, Ihre Großzügigkeit zu belohnen und in Kontakt zu bleiben, wenn Sie eine der verfügbaren Vergünstigungen wählen.
Die Geschichte der Newill Academy begann im Jahr 2010, als Herr William Newman, ein ghanaischer Lehrer einen Kindergarten in einem leeren Lagerhaus neben dem Haus seiner Mutter in Koforidua gründete. Sein Ziel ist es, qualitativ hochwertige Kindertagesstätten und Schulung für bedürftigte Kinder in der Region, vor allem die Kinder der Marktverkäufer und Straßenverkäufer, die nicht leisten können, zu Hause bleiben mit ihnen zu bleiben. Als die Kinder wuchsen, wuchs die Akademie zusammen mit ihnen, und primäre Klassen wurden gestartet. Die Schule arbeitet auf einer gemeinnützigen Basis, die Studenten zahlen eine minimale Gebühr, die nur das Lehrergehalt, den Transport durch den Schulbus und eine Mahlzeit pro Tag abdeckt.
Obwohl der Gründer und Schulleiter der Schule zusammen mit der Lehrkräfte hart daran arbeiten, das Beste für die Schüler zu geben, liegt die Akademie im Mangel an ordnungsgemäßem finanziellen Hintergrund vor verschiedenen Herausforderungen. Zuerst ist es überfüllt, die Infrastruktur reicht für die Anzahl der Schüler nicht aus. Die Kinder sind begeistert auf das Studium, aber anstatt der Klassenzimmer bleiben sie in temporären, schutzähnlichen Strukturen, die den verschiedenen Wetterbedingungen ausgesetzt sind. Sanitäranlagen müssen ebenfalls verbessert werden.
Eine Gruppe europäischer Architekten hat in enger Zusammenarbeit mit dem örtlichen Management die Pläne im Jahr 2016 überarbeitet und im Sommer 2016 mit den Bauarbeiten des kostengünstigen, nachhaltigen Schulgebäudes angefangen. In den nächsten Jahren sollen zwei weitere Bauphasen folgen, um die Akademie abzuschließen der komfortablen und passenden Platz für die 240 Schüler bietet.
Um Baukosten und zukünftige Instandhaltung niedrig zu halten, sind lokal verfügbare Materialien, handgefertigte Strukturen, passive Lüftung und ein Regenwassernutzungsanlage enthalten. Die Ziegel sind handgefertigt, produziert vor Ort von Freiwilligen. Innenelemente und Teile der Fassade sind aus Bambus gefertigt, im nahe gelegenen Wald gesammelt. Das erhöhte Dach dientsolar chimney als Solarkamin und erzeugt so eine natürliche Luftbewegung, wenn er von der Sonne aufgewärmt wird.
Das Projekt wurde vom Medienarchitekturpreis 2016 verliehen, einer der bedeutendsten Preise zeitgenössischer von Architektur in Ungarn. 
 
Design:
  Bogdan Funk
  Balazs Szelecsenyi
  Orsolya Vadasz
  Dia Nusszer
  Csinszka Cserhati
Bauingenieur:
  Daniel Veto
Nachhaltige Systeme:
  Roland Nemeth (www.tectobio.com)
Visualisierung:
  Gabor Gyenese (www.gyga.ch)
Video:
  Lilla Vaczi
 
HU
Számos támogatónk nagylelkű adományának köszönhetően 2016 és 2017 nyarán felépíthettük a Newill Academy új iskolaépületének földszintjét és megkezdhettük az első emeleti falak építését. Ezek a szerkezetkész helyiségek már használatban vannak, megkönnyítve a 240 diák mindennapjait.  Gyűjtöttünk továbbá bambuszt melyet előkészítettünk a homlokzaton való felhasználásra.
Idén az augusztusi tanítási szünetben az első emeleti három tanterem és könyvtárhelyiség befejezését tervezzük, valamint a legfelső szint falainak felállítását.
A beérkezett adományokat teljes egészében a Newill Academy fejlesztésére fordítjuk, elsősorban építőanyagok vásárlására és a helyi munkaerő bérének fedezésére. A munka javát önkéntesekből álló csapatunk fogja elvégezni. Légy te is a változás részese! Támogathatsz minket név nélkül is, de örömmel könszönetet mondanánk nagylelkűségedért amennyiben az alábbi opciók közül választasz és megadod elérhetőséged.
A Newill Akadémia története 2010-ben kezdődött, amikor William Newman, egy helyi tanár az édesanyja koforiduai háza melletti üres melléképületben egy szociális alapon működő óvodát és általános iskolát indított. Az intézmény hiánypótló, hiszen a városban nem, illetve csak nagyon drágán áll rendelkezésre hasonló ellátás, a hátrányosabb helyzetű szülők a mindennapi megélhetés előteremtésével vannak elfoglalva, nem tudnak családjukkal otthon maradni. Az intézmény aztán az évek során a gyerekekkel együtt nőtt, és hamarosan általános iskolai osztályok is indultak.
Az évek alatt az iskola kinőtte az eredeti épületet, mára több osztály terem híján folyosókon vagy az udvaron felállított egyszerű tető alatt tanul. Már évekkel ezelőtt tervek készültek az iskola fejlesztésére, megfelelő anyagi háttér hiányában azonban csak egy új épülettömb alapozása és lábazata készült el.
Ekkor magyar építészek egy lelkes csoportja a helyi vezetéssel együttműködve és a fenntarthatóságot valamint a klimatikus viszonyokat szem előtt tartva továbbfejlesztették a terveket. Az eredeti tervekből megmaradt a 3 szintes épület és az L alakú alaprajz, optimalizálva lett viszont a nyílásosztás, a közlekedés rendszere, továbbá közösségi terek kerültek kialakításra és az udvarral való kapcsolat is át lett fogalmazva. Trópusi éghajlaton a legfontosabb tervezési szempont az árnyékolás és szellőzés biztosítása, ezt mélyen ülő lamellás ablakokkal, nagy tetőkinyúlással, az osztálytermek perforált falaival valamint a folyosó felőli oldalon hézagos bambusz homlokzati burkolattal igyekeztünk elérni. A zárófödémtől elemelt fémlemez tető hamar felmelegszik ezért napkéményként tud működni, a felszálló meleg levegő elvét kihasználva biztosítja a tantermek természetes szellőzését.
A projekt 2016-ban elnyerte a média Építészeti Díja közönségdíját, mely a kortárs építészet egyik legjelentősebb elismerése Magyarországon.

  Bogdan Funk
  Balazs Szelecsenyi
  Orsolya Vadasz
  Dia Nusszer
  Csinszka Cserhati
statika:
  Daniel Veto
fenntartható rendszerek:
  Roland Nemeth (www.tectobio.com)
látvány:
  Gabor Gyenese (www.gyga.ch)
videó:
  Lilla Vaczi

story:
Overview

Wells Fargo has partnered with the Birmingham Education Foundation (Ed) by offering us a $25,000 challenge grant. If you contribute to Ed before May 31st, Wells Fargo will match your gift dollar-for-dollar up to $25,000. If we meet our goal of $25,000, we will be able to support an additional 500 students in the Birmingham City Schools through our various programs, ensuring that more deserving children are on the path to college and career readiness. Please help us take advantage of this generous offer and contribute today!

Mission and Background

Ed dedicates itself to ensuring all of the 24,494 students in the Birmingham City Schools are on the path to college and career readiness by acting as a connectors between our schools and the community.  Our mission is to bring the voice of the community to Birmingham City Schools’leadership; to listen to and work alongside educators, students, and families; and to ensure equitable access to educational opportunities for all students in the Greater Birmingham Community.

Our Impact

Ed has four main priorities that all align with our overall mission of improving college and career readiness in the Birmingham City Schools. These include:

1. Expanding the number of students who are graduating college and career ready

2. Expanding the number of elementary and middle school students on the path to graduating college and career ready

3. Expanding the number of students who master the essential skills necessary for success in college and their careers

4. Expanding the number of students who have access to college and career resources

In addition to our four priorities, some of our programs in the Birmingham City Schools include:

ACT Prep at Ramsay High School

In the 2014-2015 school year, Ed was able to partner with College Admission Made Possible (CAMP) to provide ACT and PSAT prep to sophomores, juniors, and seniors at Ramsay. In both cases, students saw significant improvement, and beginning in 2015-2016, Ed will bring ACT & PSAT prep to double the number of students with a goal of averaging a 10% increase on their respective scores. As a reward for participation and growth, students will also have access to college visits around the southeastern United States. 

Career Development Conferences

Approximately 400-800 middle and high school students participate in a yearlong program as part of the Rotary and Ed Career Development Conference and Professional Skills Curriculum, to help students hone their professional skills, establish professional networks, and gain experience in business/interviewing practices.

(Students at our second annual Career Development Conference on interviewing skills, the third iteration of the program produced in partnership with the Birmingham Rotary Club)

College 101

College 101 programming is developed as part of a year-long campaign to support a growing college-going culture in Birmingham City high schools. In 2014-2015, College 101 expanded its reach, engaging in or facilitating college tours, college admission officer visits, and classroom presentations on college preparedness. During the 2015-2016 school year, College 101 will continue to expand to serve more students in all seven Birmingham City high schools through academic tours at UAB, College Knowledge presentations, and a college-career interest survey administered to all 10th-grade students.

(Sophomores from Woodlawn and Carver High Schools participating in our second College 101 tour of the year courtesy of the friendly folks at UAB Admissions)

Bridging the Gap

Bridging the Gap is a career-preparatory program for students in the Birmingham City Schools Career Academies, modeled after a partnership with the UAB Health System. Students gain exposure to a wide variety of careers through monthly tours and lectures facilitated by local business and industry partners at locations like UAB Hospitals, Regions Bank, Alabama Power, and the Southern Museum of Flight. 

(Huffman High School students sit in on a presentation at Brasfield & Gorie, one of many activities they participated in during a tour of the corporate office)

Raise Up Initiatives

Raise Up Initiatives exist to support and build Ed's Network of students, families, educators, local residents, and volunteers in Birmingham, where Ed serves as the "Connector" of these five groups. Raise Up Initiatives such as Network Night and our Connector fellowship (a leadership program for students, educators, parents, and local residents) support new, intentional spaces where diverse groups of Network members build supportive relationships, engage in value exchange, and co-create visions that will increase student achievement -- both personally and academically. Ed recognizes that many of the people who care about students do not spend time together connecting, exchanging, or pursuing collective visions. We believe that they are hungry to connect, and the Raise Up Initiatives make connecting in real time and space a reality!

(This past February, we hosted our second Network Night at Carver High School where over 100 people attended and discussed various ways to get involved in the community)

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please help us share our story and meet our goal!
  • Post the link to our campaign page on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, and other social networking sites.
  • Ask your friends and family to join the campaign.  You can even create your own fundraising page to see how much you can raise

story:
Haskell Web Development Book

Update 4 (Nov. 28): we're down to the final stretch! I've added one new perk (Digital Tutor) and I've greatly improved the workshop offering (2-days -> 5-days, same price). I'll be writing a detailed overview of the workshops soon, to better explain what that looks like for interested supporters.

I'll be working actively this coming week to communicate more broadly and help make this happen. Thanks so much to everyone who has funded this effort so far!

Update 3 (Nov. 05): realizing that I perks are immutable once received, I can't request a shipping address on the existing Full Sponsor perk. If you'd like to receive a print copy of the book along with the benefits of being a Full Sponsor, I've created a new perk that does exactly that. Thanks for all your support!

Update 2 (Nov. 05): clarification - all Full Sponsor tier supporters will receive 1 print copy of the book.

Update 1 (Nov. 02): by popular demand, shipping for print copies is now available internationally!

Hi! My name is Allele Dev. I want to write a book that teaches Haskell for web development. It's my goal to provide a freely available text that builds on existing Haskell texts like:

  • Real World Haskell
  • Parallel and Concurrent Haskell
  • Haskell Programming From First Principles
  • Haskell and Yesod

- with a focus on practical backend Haskell. I will expand on those books and provide more coverage on topics like:

  • Modern Haskell project, build, and dependency management
  • Library evaluation and selection: routing, JSON, storage, and more
  • Data modeling with types: connecting logic to storage and views
  • Testing: property-based, spec-based, doc-tests, and ad-hoc
  • Benchmarking: end-to-end and component-based
  • Profiling
  • Metrics collection, logging, and error-handling

I've worked in Haskell web development for over a year now, in Haskell for three years, and in web development in general for three years. I'm comfortable writing on technical subjects, as well as writing code. I've taught Haskell at every company I've been employed at, and I've hosted two workshops teaching Haskell this year:

  • Build Haskell Web Services (2h) @ Strangeloop
  • Build Haskell Web Services (3.5h) @ Code Mesh
This book will be a gift from me to everyone, and it is exactly what I want to be working on. Help me make it happen!

What I Need & What You Get

I want to work full-time on this book for 3 months. $20,000 covers my cost of living for that long.

For this much support, I guarantee that the following will be completed within 3 months. This is the core of the project:

  • Source code (BSD-3 licensed) freely available with guaranteed reproducible builds via stack
  • Source for book chapters available under CC-BY-4.0 license
  • Instructions to build PDF/ePUB using pandoc
  • Exercises for each chapter
  • Solutions linked separately (spoiler-free!) for all exercises
  • Explanations for given solutions
  • Public issue tracker for typos/clarifications/etc.
  • Support for 3 months after the project for addressing issues

The book will always be freely available.

Here is a preliminary outline of the book chapters:

Testing will be a focus throughout. After being introduced in chapter 4, tests will be used along with code snippets when introducing new ideas. This will develop a coding style that makes effective use of types where possible, yet continues to validate assumptions during development.

Each chapter will also give some coverage to relevant, alternative libraries. There's many ways to do things in Haskell, and I intend to  provide a sampling of that variety.


Perks

Several perks are being offered in the process of writing this book. I plan to begin servicing them as soon as the funding goal is reached. I will dedicate 30 hours per month towards perk fulfillment and 120-140 hours per month towards book writing.

Some perks allow you to pre-purchase a print version of the book. Currently, I plan to use Amazon CreateSpace publishing services for generating print copies of the book. These will be delivered at the end of the 3-month writing period and will contain:

  • table of contents
  • CC-BY 4.0 license text
  • core content, including relevant in-line code snippets
  • exercises
  • select solutions
  • index

Stretch goal content will be released progressively thereafter in digital-only form.

For now, delivery of the print copies of the books is limited to the USA. I will investigate international shipping options and determine how to provide this perk for international backers.

For all perks, the following terms apply:

  • I refuse to promote slurs or bigoted content. This applies especially to tweets and sponsor-style perks.

Underfund Goals

If I do not meet the goals, here's what can be expected:



Stretch Goals

If I do meet the minimum goal, there's a lot more I can write about to make the coverage more comprehensive! In particular, I can add chapters on:

  • Frontend development: PureScript, Elm, GHCJS, Om, etc.
  • Haskell HTTP API Clients
  • Foreign Function Interface: C, Rust, C++
  • Other serialization: XML, HTML, etc.
  • More abstraction and type techniques for safer code
  • Performance tuning
  • Advanced authentication/authorization
  • Interfacing with other systems
  • Additional storage engines: document stores, file system, etc.
  • Caching
  • Data streaming
If I make it to the minimum funding point, I will announce a poll that allows funders to choose in what order these will be addressed. You're welcome to suggest additional topics of interest.

For every additional $3000, I will dedicate half a month towards providing coverage on one of these topics in the order determined by poll votes.


Risks & Challenges

The primary risk is that I won't be able to write the core of the book in three months.

In the case that I don't complete the primary content in three months for whatever reason, here's the contingency plan:
  • Dedicate a quarter of my time each month towards completing the book
  • Seek additional funding via Patreon to cover my living costs

Content will be published while the book is in development, so you'll be able to track progress!

Another potential risk: what if breaking changes appear in the Haskell web development ecosystem? Here's a few possibilities and how I plan to deal with them:

  • New compiler, GHC 8.0: book targets GHC 7.10 and ensures builds via stack
  • Library changes will be dealt with similarly


Project Timeline

  • November 2015: Campaign
  • December 2015: book website, first 3 chapters
  • January 2016: next 4 chapters
  • February 2016: remaining core chapters
  • March 2016: print copies ship, honoring perks, stretch goal writing
  • April 2016: honoring remaining perks, stretch goal writing
  • 2016: stretch goal writing  


Other Ways You Can Help

Let others know I'm working on this! Tweet about the campaign. Let me know what you think.
