The book will always be freely available.
Here is a preliminary outline of the book chapters:


Testing will be a focus throughout. After being introduced in chapter 4, tests will be used along with code snippets when introducing new ideas. This will develop a coding style that makes effective use of types where possible, yet continues to validate assumptions during development.
Each chapter will also give some coverage to relevant, alternative libraries. There's many ways to do things in Haskell, and I intend to  provide a sampling of that variety.

Perks
Several perks are being offered in the process of writing this book. I plan to begin servicing them as soon as the funding goal is reached. I will dedicate 30 hours per month towards perk fulfillment and 120-140 hours per month towards book writing.
Some perks allow you to pre-purchase a print version of the book. Currently, I plan to use Amazon CreateSpace publishing services for generating print copies of the book. These will be delivered at the end of the 3-month writing period and will contain:

table of contents
CC-BY 4.0 license text

core content, including relevant in-line code snippets

exercises
select solutions

index

Stretch goal content will be released progressively thereafter in digital-only form.
For now, delivery of the print copies of the books is limited to the USA. I will investigate international shipping options and determine how to provide this perk for international backers.
For all perks, the following terms apply:
I refuse to promote slurs or bigoted content. This applies especially to tweets and sponsor-style perks.

Underfund Goals
If I do not meet the goals, here's what can be expected:



Stretch Goals
If I do meet the minimum goal, there's a lot more I can write about to make the coverage more comprehensive! In particular, I can add chapters on:

Frontend development: PureScript, Elm, GHCJS, Om, etc.
Haskell HTTP API Clients

Foreign Function Interface: C, Rust, C++
Other serialization: XML, HTML, etc.

More abstraction and type techniques for safer code
Performance tuning
Advanced authentication/authorization
Interfacing with other systems
Additional storage engines: document stores, file system, etc.
Caching

Data streaming

If I make it to the minimum funding point, I will announce a poll that allows funders to choose in what order these will be addressed. You're welcome to suggest additional topics of interest.For every additional $3000, I will dedicate half a month towards providing coverage on one of these topics in the order determined by poll votes.
Risks & Challenges
The primary risk is that I won't be able to write the core of the book in three months.In the case that I don't complete the primary content in three months for whatever reason, here's the contingency plan:
Dedicate a quarter of my time each month towards completing the book

Seek additional funding via Patreon to cover my living costs

Content will be published while the book is in development, so you'll be able to track progress!
Another potential risk: what if breaking changes appear in the Haskell web development ecosystem? Here's a few possibilities and how I plan to deal with them:

New compiler, GHC 8.0: book targets GHC 7.10 and ensures builds via stack
Library changes will be dealt with similarly



Project Timeline

November 2015: Campaign
December 2015: book website, first 3 chapters
January 2016: next 4 chapters
February 2016: remaining core chapters
March 2016: print copies ship, honoring perks, stretch goal writing
April 2016: honoring remaining perks, stretch goal writing
2016: stretch goal writing  

  
Other Ways You Can HelpLet others know I'm working on this! Tweet about the campaign. Let me know what you think.

story:
100 STORIES TO PASS ON TO YOUR DAUGHTER

The First 100 Years is a ground-breaking history project, supported by the Law Society and the Bar Council, charting the journey of women in law since 1919.

We are making 100 films charting the stories of 100 women lawyers past and present to pass on as legacy to future generations. 

What benefits you receive

  • Your name on the Digital Wall of Donors inside the Digital Museum archived by the British Library 

  • Your name as a supporter on the First 100 Years website (www.first100years.org.uk)

  • A personal invitation to share your stories, photographs, letters and documents with the First 100 Years project

  • The chance to become a First 100 Years Champion – an inspiring woman in law

  • The opportunity to write for the First 100 Years website and blog, setting out your stories, views and opinions on the journey of women in law since 1919

  • The opportunity to be featured in one of the project’s 100 video stories

    Donors of £1,000 or more will be members of the project's 100 Club, receiving regular updates about the project as well as one complimentary ticket per year to our First 100 Years events ; our annual flagship conference and In Conversation series.  

The impact you will help to make

The First 100 Years project is marking the centenary of the Sex Disqualification (Removal) Act 1919 which paved the way for women to become lawyers for the first time. The project will chart the journey of women in law from 1919 to present day. As a valued supporter, you will help the First 100 Years project celebrate the past to shape the future for women in law - delivering real and positive impact across the legal profession;

  • Capturing the 100 most important stories of women in law since 1919

  • Creating positive role models for women on law

  • Highlighting the key issues women in law have faced, and still face today

  • Bringing all sides of the legal sector together to celebrate the past and shape the future for women in law. Creating a cross-sector platform for intelligent debate and change

  • Creating a deeper understanding of the role of women in law, from 1919 to today

  • Building an archive and a legacy for students to access for free


Other ways you can help and support the First 100 Years project

  • Share your stories and ideas. We want to hear from about women who inspired your career, to help build a comprehensive timeline of women’s role and rise in the profession.

  • Share your law firm’s heritage; documents, letters, biographies, photographs and stories of inspirational women. Email yourstory@first100years.org.uk

  • Follow us on Twitter @first100years, LinkedIn and Facebook.

  • Ask your company to become a corporate donor. Sponsorship packages are available for those that wish to get more involved. Get in touch with the team to hear more. 

  • Let us know your reasons for being a supporter - why is this project important to you?

  • Tell your colleagues and contacts about the First 100 Years.

story:
Dear Friends, I need your help.
Hello, I'm Oyun-Erdene a.k.a Oku, a Mongolian studying Energy Engineering at Penn State. I've chosen this path because the ultimate goal of mine is to exterminate the EXCESSIVE AIR POLLUTION in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. All the citizens in Ulaanbaatar, even my family, is inhaling this air pollution right now. To achieve my goal, I'm not only going to classes but also grasping every opportunity around me and make it useful. One way of doing that is to go to Iceland this winter via the Green Program. I just got accepted to Iceland Winter Program (January 3 - 10, 2016) and will be exploring world's leading hydroelectric, biofuel, geothermal, and wind energy facilities. However, the program costs $3700 and unfortunately I wasn't been able to find any scholarship from Penn State for they frankly don't offer it for "Winter" Programs but for Summer programs. Thus, I end up with one thing which is asking for your help :) help me get closer to my goal and fight Air Pollution in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Even the small donation will help! Thank you!
If you want look at more details about the Green Program here's the link:http://thegreenprogram.com/otw2…/iceland-winterspring-8-day/


Сайн байна уу, фэйсбүүк дэх найз нар аа. Надад та нарын тусламж хэрэг болоод байна. Зарим нь мэдэх байх, намайг Пенн Стэйтийн их сургуульд Сэргээгдэх Эрчим Хүчний Инженерээр сурдгийг. Би энэ мэргэжлийг Улаанбаатар хот дахь хортой хэмжээнээс хэтэрчихээд байгаа утааг устгаж арилгахын тулд сонгосон юм. Улаанбаатар хот дахь бүх л хүн, миний аав ээж дүү нар гээд бүгд л энэ хортой утааг яг одоо ч уушиглаж байгаа. Би өөрийн тавьсан зорилгодоо хүрэхийн тулд ганц хичээлдээ суугаад зогсохгүй эргэн тойронд байгаа надад хэрэгтэй боломж бололцоо бүрийг ашиглаад авахыг зорин хичээж байгаа билээ.  Эзэн хичээвэл заяа хичээнэ гэдэг нь биелээд Ногоон хөтөлбөр гэх том сургалтанд хамрагдахаар тэнцээд энэ өвөл 1 сарын 3-с 10-ны хооронд Исланд улсын Reykjavik University(Рейкжавикийн их сургууль)уруу очиж 7 хоногийн эрчимжүүлсэн сургалтанд суухаар боллоо. Энэ сургалтаар дамжуулаад дэлхийд тэргүүлэх усан цахилгаан станц, биотүлш, газрын гүний дулаан болон салхний эрчим хүчний станц уруу очиж үзэн, судалгаа хийж туршлага судлах юм. Мэдээж ийм гоё юм болох учраас гарах зардал нь үнэтэй. 3700 доллар босгох шаардлага гарсан учраас найз нөхөд, ах эгч та нарын туслалцааг хүсэж байгаа нь энэ юм. Сургуулиасаа олон улсын(америкийн иргэн биш) гэсэн шалтгаанаар тэтгэлэг авах боломжгүй байгаа юм. Та бүхэн надад боломжоороо тусалж миний болон Улаанбаатарт амьдардаг хүн бүрын хүсэл болсон утааг арилгах зорилгод минь хувь нэмрээ оруулаарай. Баярлалаа. Миний явах гэж байгаа Ногоон хөтөлбөрийн талаар энэ линкээр орж харж болно. http://thegreenprogram.com/otw2…/iceland-winterspring-8-day/

story:
Saint Louis Lady Arm Wrestlers are back at The Way Out Club for our second event of 2015 on Saturday, April 11th! This evening is all about female empowerment, crazy shenanigans, burlesque + WWE-style Theatrics + ARM WRESTLING!

All money raised at the event (EVERY DOLLAR!!!) goes to support Immigrant & Refugee Women's Program. 

Support your favorite wrestler by sponsoring them here to help IRWP raise more from the bout. For those who can't attend the event, sponsoring a wrestler is a great way to throw in your support and make it an even more successful evening! The winning wrestler will earn extra bragging rights for their philanthropic, fundraising might!

About Immigrant & Refugee Women's Program:

The mission of Immigrant & Refugee Women's Program (IRWP) is to increase the independence and reduce the isolation of immigrant and refugee women by teaching them basic English and practical living skills in the security of their own homes.  IRWP's volunteer teachers provide one-on-one instruction that includes speaking, reading, and writing English for 2 hours per week.  They work towards the student’s personal goals of employment, citizenship, or basic communication skills with others in order to become active members of the community.  In 2014, 149 volunteers taught 158 students through 6,056 hours of class time.

More about the event:

 Horchata Dentana will be gracing us with her dynamite presence and the glorious Greta Garter will be joining us for her first ever SLLAW event. Don't miss Bryce Bordello -- word on the street is that he'll be sporting a fluffy bunny tail for the occasion. 

Hosted by SinDee Hoo Hoo and Little Eadie Beatie.

Sound Design and Dance Party by DJ Dolly PartYon.

SLLAW : Saint Louis Lady Arm Wrestlers welcomes the 67th Annual Gateway Ruggerfest Tournament for a half-time show you don't want to miss! Those Rugby Women know how to throw down a good time.

story:
I'm 32, I write stories, I have crummy digestion, I like to meditate, and I need your help!

I've been practicing meditation for about six years, mostly on my own. I'd like to practice more seriously for a while. I'm registered for the three-month (84-day) silent meditation retreat at Insight Meditation Center in Barre, Massachusetts. Because the retreat is silent (no talking, no internet, no reading, no writing (yikes!)), I won't be able to do my usual work during that time. I also need to pay for my room and board while I'm on retreat and buy a plane ticket to Barre. 

 

I need your help to make this happen.

By contributing, you'll be helping me attend the retreat!

If I reach my goal, I'll be able to pay off my balance in full (I owe $2500) and go on the retreat! A small percent of the funds will go to Indiegogo for their fee (4% if I reach my goal, 9% if I don't). 

If I exceed my goal, I'll use contributions to pay for my plane ticket to and from Barre, and if there's more after that, I'll donate it to IMS's scholarship fund, which has helped me attend retreats in the past.

Although I made up some different "perks," which you'll see over on the right, I value all contributions equally because any help really does help--it all gets me a little closer to making this retreat possible. If you can't contribute money but want to help, please spread the word!

 

Why am I doing this now?

Attending a long retreat is something I've looked forward to (and feared!) during the six years I've been practicing meditation. Right now, the timing is right, and I have support at home to go. 

What I hear from people who have attended the three-month retreat is overwhelmingly positive. The little glimpse I've had of the possibilities during ten-day retreats also suggests to me the huge value of a longer stretch of silence. Although I know this is going to be difficult for me (I am very restless!), I'm determined to do it. The timing is right, and I have the motivation, so I figure I better not waste any time. I'm really excited (and a little scared) to go, and grateful to have had so much support so far.

 

There are other ways to help!

Any noise you can make about my campaign is great! Indiegogo has some tools on this page for sharing. You can also link this page on your own from Facebook and Twitter and other places I don't even know about.

I'll post updates, so check back here occasionally if you're curious.

Thank you!

story:
A vexing obstacle in the search for sasquatch has been the inability to successfully extract and sequence DNA from hair samples attributed to sasquatch on the basis of their distinctive morphology. Recent headlines have expounded the discovery of DNA of the enigmatic Denisovan hominins using environmental DNA (eDNA) survey methods, despite the lack of any physical or trace evidence of Denisovans occupying the cave. The potential for application of eDNA methods to the sasquatch question is obvious.The key to successful results is identifying the appropriate sample site. Recently, members of the Olympic Project, a group of citizen scientist investigators in Washington state, became aware of multiple ground nests of distinctive construction, yielding hairs of an unknown hominoid. Expert opinion is that these unusual nest were not made by bears. This seemed to be an ideal situation for an eDNA survey.

 

 

 

 

My name is Dr. Jeff Meldrum. I am a professor of anatomy and anthropology at Idaho State University and have considered the question of sasquatch from various angles for over two decades. I was invited by Derek Randles, of the Olympic Project, to visit the site and examine the nests, their location, concentration, and construction. I was stunned. The nests were typically underlain with a foundation of medium diameter sticks overlain with huckleberry boughs that had been apparently manually pulled off the ends of the surrounding bushes that formed and effective 7-foot screen.  The boughs were jammed in stem first and plaited into the marginal ring.  Soil samples were collected under sterile conditions and await eDNA analysis.

My colleague Dr. Todd Disotell, a molecular anthropologist at New York University, has remained open-minded about the possible existence of sasquatch and has analyzed tissue samples of interest in the past. Dr. Disotell, who first suggested to me the prospects of eDNA as a tool to get at this perplexing objective, has agreed to conduct the surveys this Fall once funding is secured. The cost to carry out the analysis is approximately $1000 per sample.

 

 

 

 

It should not be surprising that the physical remains of sasquatch have yet to be secured. An extremely rare and reclusive species, solitary, perhaps nocturnal, far ranging, long-lived -- these attributes make the discovery  challenging. How often does one stumble on a a bear carcass that died a natural death? Or more to the point, something like a wolverine, or a marten? The alignment of these two factors -- improvements in eDNA protocols and the identification of what is most likely a sasquatch nesting site -- provide a novel opportunity to perhaps finally get the novel DNA sequence we have been searching for.  You can participate in this scientific endeavor through your contributions to fund the eDNA analysis.  To show our appreciation, I am offering the following perks:

donations of $100  a Sasquatch Field Guide...

...plus a Skype conversation with me.

 

donations of $300, Sasquatch: Legend Meets Science...

...a soft-cover book (320 pages) inspired by the acclaimed Discovery Channel documentary, and over 10 years of scientific investigation by the author.

 

donations of $500, a replica footprint cast taken on the Olympic Penninsula.

accompanied by a frame-able description of the discovery and analysis...

Thank you for your interest and support!
story_txt: A vexing obstacle in the search for sasquatch has been the inability to successfully extract and sequence DNA from hair samples attributed to sasquatch on the basis of their distinctive morphology. Recent headlines have expounded the discovery of DNA of the enigmatic Denisovan hominins using environmental DNA (eDNA) survey methods, despite the lack of any physical or trace evidence of Denisovans occupying the cave. The potential for application of eDNA methods to the sasquatch question is obvious.The key to successful results is identifying the appropriate sample site. Recently, members of the Olympic Project, a group of citizen scientist investigators in Washington state, became aware of multiple ground nests of distinctive construction, yielding hairs of an unknown hominoid. Expert opinion is that these unusual nest were not made by bears. This seemed to be an ideal situation for an eDNA survey.    My name is Dr. Jeff Meldrum. I am a professor of anatomy and anthropology at Idaho State University and have considered the question of sasquatch from various angles for over two decades. I was invited by Derek Randles, of the Olympic Project, to visit the site and examine the nests, their location, concentration, and construction. I was stunned. The nests were typically underlain with a foundation of medium diameter sticks overlain with huckleberry boughs that had been apparently manually pulled off the ends of the surrounding bushes that formed and effective 7-foot screen.  The boughs were jammed in stem first and plaited into the marginal ring.  Soil samples were collected under sterile conditions and await eDNA analysis.My colleague Dr. Todd Disotell, a molecular anthropologist at New York University, has remained open-minded about the possible existence of sasquatch and has analyzed tissue samples of interest in the past. Dr. Disotell, who first suggested to me the prospects of eDNA as a tool to get at this perplexing objective, has agreed to conduct the surveys this Fall once funding is secured. The cost to carry out the analysis is approximately $1000 per sample.    It should not be surprising that the physical remains of sasquatch have yet to be secured. An extremely rare and reclusive species, solitary, perhaps nocturnal, far ranging, long-lived -- these attributes make the discovery  challenging. How often does one stumble on a a bear carcass that died a natural death? Or more to the point, something like a wolverine, or a marten? The alignment of these two factors -- improvements in eDNA protocols and the identification of what is most likely a sasquatch nesting site -- provide a novel opportunity to perhaps finally get the novel DNA sequence we have been searching for.  You can participate in this scientific endeavor through your contributions to fund the eDNA analysis.  To show our appreciation, I am offering the following perks:donations of $100  a Sasquatch Field Guide......plus a Skype conversation with me. donations of $300, Sasquatch: Legend Meets Science......a soft-cover book (320 pages) inspired by the acclaimed Discovery Channel documentary, and over 10 years of scientific investigation by the author. donations of $500, a replica footprint cast taken on the Olympic Penninsula.accompanied by a frame-able description of the discovery and analysis...Thank you for your interest and support!

story:
Established in 2006, PFEEF (Personal Finance Employee Education Foundation) is an organization that advocates employee financial well-being and satisfaction. We believe that financial education, provided by employers, empowers employees to be more productive. This leads to a more sustainable work environment and higher employer profits.

Helping employees help themselves is a top priority of PFEEF, and we hope to inform and invite employers to make this a top priority as well. With data gathered from over 100,000 individuals, PFEEF created a benchmark used by employers to analyze the financial well-being of employees.  PFEEF acts as a neutral third party to connect employers with quality providers who offer individualized training and financial literacy plans.  Your donations will enable PFEEF to reach more employers and, in turn, help more employees achieve greater financial well-being.

One in three Americans suffers from financial stress. Research shows that financial stress among employees negatively impacts company profits and productivity. For example, turnover, absenteeism, payroll expenses, and stress associated healthcare cost employers over $100 billion dollars a year.  Estimates indicatethat employers will spend $7 billion this year on financial wellness programs and education.

PFEEF offers a short, eight-question research-based survey that will measure the financial wellness of your employees.  The information provided will enable HR managers to make informed decisions about their employees’ financial education needs. PFEEF can then recommend appropriate quality providers and a level of educational training that fits the needs of the group.

Financially stable employees are more productive, engaged, and satisfied. Staples, who employs approximately 50,000 people, loses more than $35 million a year in profits and productivity as a result of employee financial stress.  After using PFEEF’s employee assessment, Staples instituted a financial literacy program according to recommendations.  A follow-up survey showed an increase in financial literacy - which can have tremendous positive benefits in productivity and improved employee wellness! 

Your contributions will be used to employ writers, social media experts, and media managers to create awareness of PFEEF’s services internationally.  The financial well being of companies will benefit individual employees, employers, and markets worldwide.  



Below is a list of rewards with detailed explanations to find out what product will work best for you to be more financially literate:

The Personal Financial Wellness (PFW) Scale:  An eight-question, self-report measure of perceived financial distress and financial well-being.  The instrument measures how people are doing along a continuum extending from negative to positive feelings about and reactions to their financial situations.  The tool has been scientifically determined by a national team of scholars to be a valid and reliable measure of personal financial wellness. At the end of the quiz, you will receive a wellness score and a recommendation for greater financial wellness.

Financial Fitness Checkup: Complete a quick and easy, 8-10 minute assessment of your current overall financial knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors to receive a personalized report of your general financial well-being and a customizable recommendation of what you can learn to improve your personal financial fitness.

Financial Fitness Challenge: Choose and complete a set of five powerful, interactive courses to guide you on your path to improved financial health. In just 10 minutes a day using any computer, tablet, or smartphone, learn how to change your financial life.  With rich content, intuitive navigation, plain-English definitions of financial terminology, easy-to-use calculators, and the convenience of anytime, anywhere access, you will find that completing your courses is a breeze. Earn certificates for each course you pass and one more certificate for also completing the Final Checkup. Before you know it, you will realize how much your financial knowledge, confidence, and behaviors have improved and you'll be eager to stay on the financial fitness highway.  Course topics include:

-Basic Personal Finance

-Saving and Investing

-Retirement Planning

-Intermediate Investing

-Financial Planning

-Building Financial Security

Keeping Score: Your Credit Report and Score Webinar: Iota provides technology, education, and coaching that improves total wellbeing.  Wellness educational programs are skill-based, practical, and designed for adult learners who want what they learn to make a difference in their lives now.  Access the one-hour webinar Keeping Score: Your Credit Report and Score.  

Money Coaching Session: My Secure Advantage money coaches are staffed, salaried professionals.  They possess a minimum of five years of professional experience in the finance industry, and the team of coaches has combined experience as Certified Financial Planners, Certified Public Accountants, former bankers, and investment specialists.  during a 30-minute one-on-one coaching session, a personal money coach will help you accomplish financial goals; offer professional confidential, and guilt-free guidance; keep accountability and structure; and provide peace of mind.

Spread the word! Post about us on your Facebook, LinkdIn, Twitter, and/or Instagram with the Indiegogo share tools. Tell your boss of your interest in financial literacy training and how it would help you be a better employee. 

To learn more, check out our website at http://pfeef.org

story:
Protecting Our Seeds, Protecting Our Future

S-ke:g Tas!

We are a delegation of Tohono O'odham community members who will be traveling with our Haudenosaunee Mohawk Brothers and Sisters to Chiapas, Mexico in February 2016. The caravan will be participating in a 10 day visit to connect, learn and share traditional methods of agriculture, seed saving, bee-keeping and exchanging of knowledge.

What We Need

We need $1,400 to cover the deposit of $200 for each of us to participate. June 1st is our deadline for our deposit! The $200 will go towards the overall cost of $1,000 per person. The $1,000 will cover food, lodging, ground transportation, materials and organizational costs. 20% of this cost will go directly to the Zapatista Community/Schools for Chiapas.

Here is our tentative itinerary for the entire trip:
Day 1: Fly out February 2015 (date TBA) and arrive to Villa Hermosa (VSA) in the state of Tabasco /1 hour drive to site at Maya Bell
Day 2:  Orientation - settle in
Day 3:  Visit Palenque 
Day 4:  Workshops
Day 5:  Workshops
Day 6:  Workshops
Day 7:  Workshops
Day 8:  Last day of Workshops 
Day 9:  Breakdown camp
Day 10: Depart from Villahermosa

The $200 will go towards our deposit. After we pay our deposits we will be focusing on fundraising, building and preparing for the rest of the costs leading up to our departure in Feb 2015, which would be the remaining $800 per person.

(Watch our for our next phase of Indiegogo fundraising efforts!)

The Impact

The Tohono O'odham Nation and the Mohawk Confederacy are two Native Nations who share international borders with Mexico and Canada. We are literally at the forefront of impacts of Immigration Policy, the North American Free Trade Agreement and the CANAMEX Corridor, three major capitalist movements that have direct effects on tribal politics and community health.

In light of these issues, we have been working hard to maintain our connection to the land, each other, sacred sites and our relatives in Mexico and Canada.  Everyday we are getting stronger, simply by being who we are, building foundations of community empowerment through our languages, traditional foods, teachings and visions for future generations. By connecting with the Zapatista Community in Chiapas, we will be bringing together three strong communities who can have a profound opportunity to create change and re-establish our connections across borders.

We will be focusing on these teachings and values while in Chiapas.

Mother Seeds of Resistance - GMO seeds / seed saving 
The Other Bee: Reviving a Mayan Tradition 
Fair Trade According to the Zapatistas 
Mayan Schools of Dignity

Our goals are to take bring these experience, teachings and connections back home to our respective communities and create new or strengthen existing culture and language programs, Immersion schools, and overall community wellness and vitality.

Our Challenges

We are community organizers, students, and visionaries who have a vision! We do not have deep pockets, but we have passion for our communities and are looking to you, our friends and family to help us in our endeavor!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute in a monetary fashion, you can still help by sharing our cause and supporting future events to raise the remaining funds for our trip.

Thank you so much! Si has pik elida!

story:
100% of ALL Donations Used For TWO Things:

  • Continue reporting and publishing our stories
  • Grant writing to sustain future operations and growth

We're using InDemand to take things a step further. The same rules we had on Kickstarter apply to our InDemand for EVERY dollar we raise. 

100% of ALL money raised goes toward our storytelling. That means we can publish more stories. It also means we can file grant applications to help ensure longevity. 


Our Site. Your Stories.


We will never agree on war. That doesn't mean we shouldn't have the conversation. We want to create a community where people can share their stories from war and from home - both military and civilian, pro-war and anti-war alike - in a constructive manner. We are using today's voices to explore the lives lost, the battles fought, and the impact of war. 

We hope you will help us document Post-9/11 conflict and educate future generations like never before. And 100% of your money pledged to our project will go toward our stories. Yes, you read that correctly, 100%. Just stories. 

All donations made to our InDemand campaign are tax-deductible through the Institute for Non-Profit News (EIN: 27-2614911). 


Read Our Story About Anthony

After you enjoy the story we've published, don't forget to back us! 


The War Horse In The News


February 15, 2016 - Huffington Post, by Christopher Mathias

February 5, 2016 - Nieman Reports, by Finbarr O'Reilly, Advisor on Visual Storytelling, The War Horse



February 4, 2016 - Foreign Policy Magazine, by Sebastian Bae

January 28, 2016 - Best Defense, Foreign Policy Magazine, by Thomas J. Brennan, Founder, The War Horse 

January 22, 2016 - Public Radio East, by Christopher Thomas

January 18, 2016 - Fishbowl NY, by Richard Horgan



January 3, 2016 - Military.com, by Hope Hodge Seck

December 26, 2015 - The Daily News, by Michael Todd

Long-Running Arguments About War

Another one of the recent articles we've published exploring the centuries-long struggle to discuss and agree on how war should be fought.

Please read the full story and don't forget to back us!


What People Are Saying


Tim Patterson - U.S. Navy Veteran of Afghanistan

  "I believe there is a real need for focused journalism on topics like the war against ISIS, veteran suicide, PTSD, the VA healthcare system, and I know Thomas Brennan personally - I think he is the ideal person to be leading this project."


David Ketron - U.S. Marine Corps Veteran, Iraq and Afghanistan

   "...You can learn more about war and how it affects all of us, loved ones, and those who have gone over themselves."


What You Can Expect From The War Horse

  • Multimedia profiles for each of the U.S. service members, interpreters, and military working dogs killed in action since 9/11.
  • The gathering of suicide demographic data for Post-9/11 deaths among veterans.



    • Investigative journalism focused on the Departments of Defense and Veterans Affairs
    • THE place to answer the question: What is war?


    War In The Classroom


    We're working with The Fessenden School for an upcoming awareness campaign that will explore homelessness, suicide, prosthesis, veteran reintegration, VA healthcare, and much more. 


    We've spent hours speaking with their classroom on FaceTime and they're fascinated by where their projects are heading. Guess what? We are too.


Behind Our Bylines


We've got award-winning journalists standing by to work on incredible stories in full multimedia. Their bylines have frequented these amazing outlets.


Our Founder and Board of Advisors


Thomas Brennan: Thomas is the founder of The War Horse and an investigative journalist. Before becoming a journalist, Thomas was a sergeant in the Marine Corps and served in Iraq and Afghanistan where he was awarded the Purple Heart. He is the recipient of a 2013 Dart Award Honorable Mention and the 2014 American Legion Fourth Estate Award for his military reporting with both The Daily News in North Carolina and the New York Times.

Bruce Shapiro: Director of the Dart Center for Journalism and Trauma and a professor at Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism. Bruce will serve as the Advisor on Ethics and Standards.

Karen Stabiner: An acclaimed author and journalist, Karen's work has appeared in The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, the Los Angeles Times, the Columbia Journalism Review, and other national publications. Karen teaches Feature Writing at Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism and brings with her years of experience in vivid storytelling. She will serve as our Advisor on Immersive Storytelling.

Kevin Cullen: A Pulitzer Prize winning investigative journalist, the author of a New York Times Best Selling book, and a Harvard Neiman. Kevin will serve as the Advisor on Editorial Content.


BriGette McCoy: A soldier in the U.S. Army from 1987 through 1991, BriGette is an advocate for women veterans and the Founder and CEO of Women Veterans Social Justice. BriGette advocates for equal access to VA care and services, Military Sexual Trauma Policy changes and services, suicide prevention and family education, and alternative therapeutic health modalities. She will serve as the Advisor on Women's Veterans Coverage.

Finbarr O'Reilly: A World Press Photo winner formerly of Reuters. Finbarr is also a Yale World Fellow, a Harvard Neiman, and a Columbia Ochberg Fellow. Finbarr has dedicated his professional and academic careers photography and studying war and trauma. He will serve as the Advisor on Visual Storytelling.

Tahlia Burton: A U.S. Air Force veteran who served six years as a Cryptologic Language Analyst translating real-time threat warnings for numerous Special Forces. She worked with many Iraqi and Afghan refugees fleeing persecution. She will serve as Advisor on Human Rights. Tahlia is currently studying Human Rights at Columbia University and is the recipient of the Air Force Achievement Medal.

Susie Reynolds Reece: Has advocated for suicide prevention since she lost her father to suicide at the age of 10. Susie has used her experiences to serve as an advocate and volunteer for multiple groups nationwide including the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention. As our Advisor on Residual Trauma, Susie will help us foster the highest ethical standards in data collection and reporting on suicide and mental health.  


Every Dollar Counts


Database and application development aren't cheap. Neither is thorough and responsible journalism. We are willing and prepared to start small and prove our worth by earning your trust, but we have a plan if we raise more than we're asking for. The more money we raise, the more stories we can tell. If we raise enough, we can begin hiring journalists to work in our office. Being able to file additional grants will help us to ensure operational costs are fully funded and sustainable.

All donations made to our InDemand campaign are tax-deductible through the Institute for Non-Profit News (EIN: 27-2614911).


$50,000: By reaching this benchmark on Kickstarter, The War Horse is now able to contract journalists to publish our first four (4) multimedia feature, and will hire a part-time administrative assistant.

What If We Raise More Than Our Goal Through OnDemand?

Thanks to the generous support of our backers on Kickstarter, we reached our initial goal.

We're using InDemand to take things a step further. The same rules apply for EVERY dollar we raise. 

100% of ALL money raised goes toward our storytelling. That means we can publish more stories. It also means we can file grant applications to help ensure longevity. Every $1 helps. If you're not on our list of backers, we hope you'll join us!

“The best way to find out if you can trust somebody is to trust them.” 
- Ernest Hemingway


OUR ROLLOUT TIMELINE


During the last 20 months, The War Horse has also been generously donated more than $250,000 in non-monetary donations such as branding, financial and legal planning, non-profit sponsorship, logo design, 18 iMac computers, furniture, and a rent-free office space. We're prepared to move forward. We just need your help getting there.
 

100% of Donations Used For TWO Things: 

  • Begin reporting and publishing our stories through freelancers and staff journalists
  • Grant writing to sustain future operations and growth


All donations made to our InDemand campaign are tax-deductible through the Institute for Non-Profit News (EIN: 27-2614911). 

By helping us continue to surpass our initial Kickstarter goal, you are giving us the opportunity to further develop our news outlet and the stories we will publish. 

If you can help us reach our goal and change journalism around the world, please pledge. We hope you will tell your friends and help us create a place where professional and community journalism come together with a purpose - to understand the topic at hand! 

We hope you'll join us on our journey and please visit our website!

Semper Fidelis,

Thomas J. Brennan
Founder, The War Horse

She worked with many Iraqi and Afghan refugees fleeing persecution. She will serve as Advisor on Human Rights. Tahlia is currently studying Human Rights at Columbia University and is the recipient of the Air Force Achievement Medal.Susie Reynolds Reece: Has advocated for suicide prevention since she lost her father to suicide at the age of 10. Susie has used her experiences to serve as an advocate and volunteer for multiple groups nationwide including the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention. As our Advisor on Residual Trauma, Susie will help us foster the highest ethical standards in data collection and reporting on suicide and mental health.  
Every Dollar Counts
Database and application development aren't cheap. Neither is thorough and responsible journalism. We are willing and prepared to start small and prove our worth by earning your trust, but we have a plan if we raise more than we're asking for. The more money we raise, the more stories we can tell. If we raise enough, we can begin hiring journalists to work in our office. Being able to file additional grants will help us to ensure operational costs are fully funded and sustainable.All donations made to our InDemand campaign are tax-deductible through the Institute for Non-Profit News (EIN: 27-2614911).$50,000: By reaching this benchmark on Kickstarter, The War Horse is now able to contract journalists to publish our first four (4) multimedia feature, and will hire a part-time administrative assistant.What If We Raise More Than Our Goal Through OnDemand?Thanks to the generous support of our backers on Kickstarter, we reached our initial goal.We're using InDemand to take things a step further. The same rules apply for EVERY dollar we raise. 100% of ALL money raised goes toward our storytelling. That means we can publish more stories. It also means we can file grant applications to help ensure longevity. Every $1 helps. If you're not on our list of backers, we hope you'll join us!“The best way to find out if you can trust somebody is to trust them.” - Ernest Hemingway
OUR ROLLOUT TIMELINE
During the last 20 months, The War Horse has also been generously donated more than $250,000 in non-monetary donations such as branding, financial and legal planning, non-profit sponsorship, logo design, 18 iMac computers, furniture, and a rent-free office space. We're prepared to move forward. We just need your help getting there. 
100% of Donations Used For TWO Things: 
Begin reporting and publishing our stories through freelancers and staff journalists
Grant writing to sustain future operations and growth

All donations made to our InDemand campaign are tax-deductible through the Institute for Non-Profit News (EIN: 27-2614911). By helping us continue to surpass our initial Kickstarter goal, you are giving us the opportunity to further develop our news outlet and the stories we will publish. If you can help us reach our goal and change journalism around the world, please pledge. We hope you will tell your friends and help us create a place where professional and community journalism come together with a purpose - to understand the topic at hand! We hope you'll join us on our journey and please visit our website!Semper Fidelis,Thomas J. BrennanFounder, The War Horse

story:
The 7th Annual Five-College Queer Gender & Sexuality Conference

It's time again for the 7th annual Five-College Queer Gender and Sexuality Conference which will take place on March 4th and 5th, 2016, at Hampshire College! For years, this conference has offered an accountable and supportive environment in which to further explore a wide range of topics and their intersections, such as race, gender, sexuality, ability, class, kink, survival strategies, and many more, in a specifically queer context.

This year's featured artists and speakers include: Sasha Alexander, Director of Membership for the Sylvia Rivera Law Project, Olympia Perez, Content Director of Black Trans Media, and J Mase III, a black/trans/queer poet/educator.

This year, during each of our workshop sessions there will be closed Queer People of Color (QPOC) sessions for folks to choose what best fits their needs throughout the weekend! We hope that these sessions will give folks space to build community among black and brown LGBTQ folks, bring new tools and perspectives to bring back to our homes, and further empower the magic QPOC have!

We strongly believe in the importance of free, accessible educational events. As such, we do not charge a registration fee to attend our conference. In years past we have raised all of the budget through internal donations, but this year we are concerned that might not be sufficient to pull off the kind of amazing event we have planned.


Why is this event important?

Queer Conference provides inclusive spaces to teach, learn, and explore concepts relating to queer identities and intersections of power. We address topics touched on in queer studies classrooms as well as in our personal and professional lives. Previous workshops include "Making Queer Family Real: Building Queer and Trans Communities of Care," "Tacit Subjects: The ‘Closet’, Caribbean Identity, and Speaking the Unspeakable,"and a Caucus on Disabled Queer and Trans Experience. This inclusive collaboration promotes opportunities for networking, sustainable community building, and organizing for social change.

Equally as important, it is an opportunity for personal discovery and growth. Students and community members can gain leadership skills through facilitating workshops and panels. All attendees are invited to spend the day learning, sharing, and making connections.


How Can You Support Us?

Our conference is two days packed with workshops, panels, educational forums, and artistic performance and keynote speakers. Your contribution will help Queer Conference  an amazing success, something that you will be proud to support!

For helping us out you have the opportunity to receive a personal thank you in our program!

If you have the means please consider donating to our fundraiser. Every amount counts!


We understand not everyone has money to donate, but sharing links about Queer Conference and our campaign is also incredibly supportive!

Register for Queer Conference now!


Select "Going" on our Facebook Event


Visit Our Webpage


Like Us on Facebook


And please share our campaign! Thank you!


For any other comments, questions, or concerns, please feel free to e-mail us at queerconf@gmail.com

story:
Anchored Christian School is an accredited private school in Bowling Green, KY.  Since 1972 ACS has been providing students with a sound, Christ-centered education which has resulted in ACT scores above national and state level, SAT scores above average, over 80% of graduates go on to higher learning and many students qualifying for nationals in the spring competition.  The teachers have given up so much in their lives to make sure that the students have the best education available, but being a private school they only get paid a fraction of what a public school teacher receives.  Instead of seeing the teaching position as a job, they see it as a calling and a ministry, always putting the students first.
 
 
With the economy being the way it is, there isn't as much money coming into the school as there has been in the past, and if we could raise $10,000 it would pay for 2 months of health care for the teachers.  That's just a small part of the bills ACS has, but the teachers have given and given so let's give a little back.  Let's show these teachers, who have sacrificed so much to educate our nation's next generation, how thankful we are for what they have done by helping insure they have health care.

story:
My Story

My name is Melissa Strojek and I am a struggling college student.  After nearly 20 years of being out of high school, I decided I wanted to achieve the dream of a degree in Computer Information Systems.  I have had to overcome a lot of adversity in my life, including being diagnosed with moderate sleep apnea which robbed me of my liveliness and nearly robbed me of my good health.  It was a major obstacle to overcome the first two quarters of school before my cpap treatment started to make a difference.  I finally have a normal energy level and avoided sleep apnea's ill affects on my health.  As tired as I was all the time, I managed to work a full time job and pull off all A's in my first quarter.  I live paycheck to paycheck and only receive a small amount of grant money.  I earned a scholarship this year that was given out at my college and I used it to help with my books.  I have student loans, but I am trying not to get too far in debt before I can get done.  I am inspired by my grandparents who were Polish immigrants and managed to come to this country with very little money, only the clothes on their back and poor conditions in the belly of a ship.  They worked hard and were very proud and grateful to be in this country with the opportunities of a lifetime.  If they can overcome the things they did, I know I can.  I also have to give credit to my mom who has been very supportive and has helped me in any capacity she has been able to.  I want to make them all proud by getting this degree and moving towards a bachelor's degree in the same field.


The Impact

Finishing school with a degree would mean the world to me and those around me.  I want a career, not just a job and I have many dreams I want to accomplish with having that career.  The financial stability a career will give me will also help me fix up my house and achieve having a family of my own.  I would also some day like to take trip to Poland to see where my ancestors came from.  These things can only be accomplished if I am able to earn a decent living and expand my horizons.


What Is Needed & What You Get

I need approximately $3,500 to comfortably finish my associates degree.  This money will be applied to both tuition (after my grant/scholarship money is taken out) and for books.  I always buy used books and rent books whenever possible so as not to waste any money I have to spend.  I am limited in perks that I can offer at this time, but am willing to give something in return for your generosity.  The first perk I will offer is a shout out on my Facebook page.  The Second perk I will offer will be a shout out on my Facebook page and a hand written thank you letter.  The third perk I will offer is a shout out on my Facebook page, a hand written letter and a copy of my grades so you can see your investment in action.  The fourth perk I will offer is all of the previous items mentioned and a promise to donate to another education related cause on this website.  It would be like paying it forward.  I believe education is the key and everyone deserves a shot at it.

Each year, St. Jude Children's Research Hospital raises millions of dollars to put toward finding cures for pediatric cancer and saving children's lives. Now, it's your turn to make a difference. 

This holiday season, Trump International Hotel & Tower New York is focusing all efforts on fundraising for The Eric Trump Foundation for St. Jude Children's Research.

Here's How It Works:

Check back with us weekly for additional bonus prizes and perks!

With the click of a button, you can make a difference this holiday season. Please pass this along to your friends and family and get the word out today!

Here is to a happy & healthy holiday season for all!

With warm regards,


The Trump International Hotel & Tower New York Team

story:
Hello! I'm Emma.

I've been performing since I was tiny, and I just achieved my dream of getting into a drama school. I am now raising the fees to start London Theatre School to study musical theatre in september 2014 and I would really appreciate your help! I will be training at pineapple and dance works every day, trained by industry professionals in singing acting and dancing. It's £11,000 per year of study without money for accomodation and travel fees, so I have a long way to go, and I am asking you to help me achieve my dream of going! Thank you so much in advance, it really means everything to me.


My performing arts history: I started ballet tap and jazz classes when I was just three years old. Since then I have also trained in latin and ballroom, freestyle, contemporary and street dance, as well as taking part in every single school production that my school did.

When I was fourteen, I was one of 140 out of 4000 auditionees accepted into the highly respected National Youth Theatre of Great Britain, an organisation that trains 14-25 year olds in acting. Alumni of the NYT include David Walliams, Dame Helen Mirren, Daniel Craig, Colin Firth, Matt Smith, Matt Lucas and many more. After my training with NYT, I went on to perform in several shows with them, and I still rely on my training today.

At secondary school, I took GCSEs in Dance Drama and a BTEC in Music, achieving results within the highest 5% of the country for my Dance GCSE. I moved on to college to study a BTEC in Musical Theatre, taking extra units outside of my timetable just to learn more about the subject. I achieved a triple distinction for my final grade.

I then went to Buckinghamshire New University to study a BA (hons) degree in Dance and Performance. During my time there, I was involved in the creation of the performing arts society, taking up the role of Chairperson in my second year. I was also actively involved in the Dance team, and was picked to be a part of the competition teams in all three years of study. In my third year, I was picked to be the choreographer of the latin team, and we have won several trophies at inter-university competitions.

I am currently writing my dissertation, and will be graduating this year. As I love learning, I decided in my second year that I would either apply for a masters degree or an intensive musical theatre course after graduating from University, and I applied for London Theatre School. Following my audition on the 1st of April 2014, I recieved a letter of acceptance for the 2014 intake.... and now I am here, frantically trying to raise money to pay for the fees!

Performing is my life, it is everything, and I have never wanted anything else. I have won lots of trophies in my lifetime for my academic skills as well as my performance ability, and have taken part and won many performance and choreography competitions as well. 

Job wise, I've been teaching dance and musical theatre to both children and adults for three years in various schools and dance schools. I also own my own princess entertainment company, providing entertainment at childrens parties and events. I have also done a lot of volunteer work, teaching adults with learning difficulties at a local care home.

Performing really is everything to me and I really would appreciate anything you can give. This school will have me training at danceworks and pineapple dance every day and will assist me in my goal of one day reaching the west end. I need to raise £11,000 per year of study, and that is without accomodation or travel fees.. so I have a long way to go!

Thank you so much for reading. You are the one.

Much love xxxxxxx

story:
The Idea

Every school year, the Network for Teaching Entrepreneurship (NFTE) Bay Area provides entrepreneurship education to more than 1,000 San Francisco Bay Area students from low-income communities. There are always a few students in each class that want to do more than learn about business, these students want to start their own businesses. To create that opportunity, we started NFTE Launch.

Fatima Vargas (pictured), for example, wanted to turn her family's recipes into a catering business. She attended NFTE Launch last summer, learned how to make a business website, received mentoring from entrepreneurs, and launched her business. Fatima has been busy since NFTE Launch, catering nearly every weekend and earning more than $3,500! 

"With what I have learned I have started my new business, Vargas Family Catering, and extended the menu. I am [also] taking cake decorating classes in order to professionally decorate cakes."

Last summer, we provided NFTE Launch to 41 students. This year we want to be able to offer NFTE Launch to 60 aspiring student entrepreneurs.

The Need

NFTE Launch works because students spend all week creating and refining and doing. Each student receives seed money at the beginning of the week that functions as investment capital for their new business.

Bret Hiyas and Josh Siapno (pictured) spent their seed money on materials and supplies to make custom bowties.

All the money we raise will go directly to NFTE Launch program costs such as student seed money, staff support, and meals for participating students (while it hasn't been proven, we have found that teen entrepreneurs eat even more than the average teenager).

The Impact

NFTE Launch is one of several successful NFTE programs, which have been shown to have tremendous positive impact. For example, self-employed NFTE Alumni who are over twenty-five and have their high school diploma earn an average annual income of $44,000, compared to $24,000 in the U.S. overall! You can read more about our impact here.

NFTE Launch allows our students to take the skills they have learned and directly apply them to a business they are passionate about. More importantly, NFTE Launch engages students in a way that traditional classrooms do not.

‘It was like pulling teeth to keep Carlos (pictured) moving forward in class during the year. But then he signed up for NFTE Launch, created a unique product, built a prototype, and was receiving offers from customers – I was impressed!.’  - Denise Gregor, NFTE Teacher, San Francisco

Read more about NFTE Launch past and present here.

Other Ways You Can Help

NFTE Launch is effective in large part because of the volunteers that work with participating students throughout the week. We also need volunteers throughout the school year to come to our classrooms as guest speakers, business plan coaches, and mentors. Sign up here to be a NFTE Volunteer.

The future generation of entrepreneurs depends on the present one, so pass along our campaign to small business owners and anyone else you know who is interested in entrepreneurship.

Thank you for getting involved!

story:
Back-ground

My name is Erin Versfeld. I first came across Athi Dyonase in June, 2013, when I volunteered for a mentorship programme run by Join the Circle, Break the Cycle - a Cape Town based NGO in South Africa. He is 18-years-old, and is just about to go into Grade 11 (his second last year of high school) at Sithembele Matiso Secondary School, in Nyanga. Nyanga has been rated as being the most dangerous township in Cape Town.

Somehow, Athi has managed to keep himself free of the gang culture in his home-town. One of the first things Athi told me about himself, was that he wants to become a doctor, and make a difference in his community. He wants to educate himself, and go to university, and improve his lot in life. However, up until this point, no one had ever told him that in order to do so, he would have to take Mathematics and Physical Sciences. As such, he neglected to take these subjects in Grade 10, and is having to pick them up in 2014, when he enters Grade 11. Though the teachers at his school are sincere in their efforts to educate their students, the reality of the situation is that this is an incredibly difficult challenge for someone who does not have regular access to the internet or quality learning materials and support.

There is an extra classes programme run at the University of Cape Town (UCT), called SHAWCO Shine, which I believe will be of immense help to Athi during the course of his studies next year. They offer English, Physical Science, and Mathematics classes, all of which Athi will be taking part in.

What We Need & What You Get

In order for Athi to take part in SHAWCO Shine, he will need:

  • R6683 (approximately $646) for the cost of the lessons themselves
  • R330 (approximately $32) for his registration fee for the programme
  • R500 (approximately $49) for the cost of his work books for the programme
  • R660 (approximately $64) for train- and taxi-fare for travelling to UCT from Nyanga once per week

If the full amount if not raised before SHAWCO Shine requires their payments, I will pay in the difference. If more than what is required is raised, then the balance will be used to buy study-guides and pay for extra Mathematics and Physical Science tutoring at Master Maths.

The Difference You Are Making

10 years from now, Athi may not become a doctor. He may not even go to med school. He may instead become a lawyer, or a chef. But he will very most likely have a child, maybe even a wife. If Athi is able to get the help he needs to be able to pass Mathematics and Physical Science next year, inspite of having missed out on a year's worth of both subjects, he will be able to offer this future family of his a far brighter future than the one he was offered as a child. He'll be able to have the chance to get a degree - an opportunity which is out of his reach without Mathematics, at the very least. He will be able to offer his child more security than he himself experienced as a child, and will not have to let his family go hungry because he doesn't have a job.

By contributing financially to this campaign, you can help give Athi the chance to make a difference future than the one statistically expected of him. And by helping change his life today, you can effect a small but significant and positive change on future generations.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that not everyone is financially able to help Athi. However, if you can tutor Mathematics, or Physical Science, or if you can offer him a lift for part of the journey between UCT and Nyanga, or even if you can offer him a job, so that he can develop his sense of self-worth through honest work, it would be greatly appreciated.
story_txt:
Back-groundMy name is Erin Versfeld. I first came across Athi Dyonase in June, 2013, when I volunteered for a mentorship programme run by Join the Circle, Break the Cycle - a Cape Town based NGO in South Africa. He is 18-years-old, and is just about to go into Grade 11 (his second last year of high school) at Sithembele Matiso Secondary School, in Nyanga. Nyanga has been rated as being the most dangerous township in Cape Town.Somehow, Athi has managed to keep himself free of the gang culture in his home-town. One of the first things Athi told me about himself, was that he wants to become a doctor, and make a difference in his community. He wants to educate himself, and go to university, and improve his lot in life. However, up until this point, no one had ever told him that in order to do so, he would have to take Mathematics and Physical Sciences. As such, he neglected to take these subjects in Grade 10, and is having to pick them up in 2014, when he enters Grade 11. Though the teachers at his school are sincere in their efforts to educate their students, the reality of the situation is that this is an incredibly difficult challenge for someone who does not have regular access to the internet or quality learning materials and support.There is an extra classes programme run at the University of Cape Town (UCT), called SHAWCO Shine, which I believe will be of immense help to Athi during the course of his studies next year. They offer English, Physical Science, and Mathematics classes, all of which Athi will be taking part in.What We Need & What You GetIn order for Athi to take part in SHAWCO Shine, he will need:
R6683 (approximately $646) for the cost of the lessons themselves
R330 (approximately $32) for his registration fee for the programme
R500 (approximately $49) for the cost of his work books for the programme
R660 (approximately $64) for train- and taxi-fare for travelling to UCT from Nyanga once per week
If the full amount if not raised before SHAWCO Shine requires their payments, I will pay in the difference. If more than what is required is raised, then the balance will be used to buy study-guides and pay for extra Mathematics and Physical Science tutoring at Master Maths.The Difference You Are Making10 years from now, Athi may not become a doctor. He may not even go to med school. He may instead become a lawyer, or a chef. But he will very most likely have a child, maybe even a wife. If Athi is able to get the help he needs to be able to pass Mathematics and Physical Science next year, inspite of having missed out on a year's worth of both subjects, he will be able to offer this future family of his a far brighter future than the one he was offered as a child. He'll be able to have the chance to get a degree - an opportunity which is out of his reach without Mathematics, at the very least. He will be able to offer his child more security than he himself experienced as a child, and will not have to let his family go hungry because he doesn't have a job.By contributing financially to this campaign, you can help give Athi the chance to make a difference future than the one statistically expected of him. And by helping change his life today, you can effect a small but significant and positive change on future generations.Other Ways You Can HelpI understand that not everyone is financially able to help Athi. However, if you can tutor Mathematics, or Physical Science, or if you can offer him a lift for part of the journey between UCT and Nyanga, or even if you can offer him a job, so that he can develop his sense of self-worth through honest work, it would be greatly appreciated.

story:
WHY SUPPORT THE "$10 SEND A YOUTH TO COLLEGE" SCHOLARSHIP FUND

....impact and empower our communities.

 

This is the key element in the mission for the Collective Empowerment Group (CEG) Cincinnati Metro Chapter that works for economic empowerment for urban and minority communities struggling with double digit unemployment and job loss, unprecedented poverty and high incidents of crime, particularly against youth.

"Saving our Youth" has been the battle cry for many years in urban communities. The question for CEG is...how can we really impact our youth? According to CEG President, Rev. Eugene Ellington, "as we enter 2014, the CEG Board of Directors beleives a major focus must be directed toward our young people. The changing economic landscape demands that our young people be more than prepared to deal with, function in and contribute to a global marketplace." In response to this mandate, the Board of Directors developed the CEG Scholars Program and is establishing its first CEG Scholarship Fund in support of our young people. The goal is to raise $3500 for the Scholarship Fund.

The Collective Empowerment Group - Cincinnati Metro Chapter is a non-profit, faith based business and consumer advocate organization that has as its mission ...impacting and empowering lives. These scholarships do just that; impact, empower and transform a young person's life.

It is the desire of CEG Board of Directors to award scholarships to three (3) youth who will be graduating in 2014 and majoring in business/business administration, to attend the college or university of their choice. These youth have the entrepreneurial spirit! For the first year, we will be awarding two $1,000 scholarships to graduating high school seniors, and junior and seniors in college. A third scholarship in the amount of $1,500 will be awarded to a post graduate level student (regardless of age) who is working on their MBA.

Although these are modest first year amounts, please know your contribution will make a profound difference in a young person's life either as encouragement to either go to college or continue their college education with a view toward graduation.

These scholarships will be presented as part of the 2014 CEG Business Excellence Awards and Annual Meeting on Friday, March 28, 2014 at the Sharonville Convention Center in Cincinnati, Ohio. For more information, visit the CEG web site at www.collectiveempowermentgroup.org.

WHO WE ARE

The Cincinnati Metro Chapter of CEG is a consortium of twenty (20) churches representing more than 12,000 congregation members and mirrors the national chapter in utilizing its numbers to leveage appropriate and much needed support from financial institutions. Unique to the Cincinnati Chapter is its Strategic Partners Program (SPP) which is comprised forty-one (41) local businesses serving the urban communitites. These businesses gives discounted products and services to the congregations of the CEG member churches. The goal of this program is to build trust and encourage ongoing support of local businesses, and track the economic impact in urban and minority communities. Support of these buinesses is a first step toward self- sufficiency and job creation. Even our young people have a clear understanding of how business and technology will impact their futures. "If we don't learn to build our own businesses, there will be no one employ neither me nor my peers. Ultimately, it is about self-preservation", says Jeff Lewis, a CEG Scholar.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP!

We hope you will join us in supporting our youth's vision and passion for business. But, don't worry if you can't contribute. You can help us and support our young people by spreading the word about the "$10 Send a Youth to College Campaign".

Tell everyone about our efforts, foward the link via your email to others asking them to do the same and join the giving.

Thank you in advance for your support of our youth!

story:
Why?

The US Education System is changing rapidly.  Schools all across the country are operating in a crisis mode.  Educational administrators and policy makers are simply out of touch with the real and individual needs of families and children today.  Teachers feel powerless and depressed, parents are frustrated, and children, sadly have become bored and pessimistic about what schools have to offer them in regards to their education and future.   

 After 20 years of teaching in a wide variety of public and private school settings, I have chosen to continue my path as a teacher, by breaking open an innovative and new model of classroom learning.  Ms. Cohen's Homeschool Classroom is a place for families who have decided to leave the constraints of the traditional school site and want to provide a more individualized, safe and supportive academic setting for their child.   

What?

Children ages 5-14 can attend The Homeschool Classroom either full or part time Monday - Friday 8:30-2:30 depending on how much a family wants to supplement their own Homeschool curriculum.  Holding current elementary certifications K-6 in Massachusetts, New York, New Mexico and California, I have extensive knowledge of the various educational benchmarks and skill requirements expected at a given age. This is reassurance for many Homeschool families who want to provide alternative education, but also want their child to keep up academically.  

With a Masters of Professional Studies of Multicultural and Humanistic Education, Ms. Cohen's Homeschool Classroom creates comfort for all children by embracing their innate gifts and unique qualities, facilitating an environment for self-confidence, discovery, truth, compassion and growth. 

Our community supports child-centered learning, critical theory, and promoting success for ALL student learning styles, especially for children who have not enjoyed their learning experiences in other settings. The building blocks of a multicultural/humanistic approach foster cooperative yet independent learning.Surrounding students in a learning environment that boosts communication and problem solving skills, students learn how to be in control of their own learning.


Where will the money go?


1. We Want to MOVE!

The Homeschool Classroom has grown in popularity since its inception in September 2011. Taking the leap to leave a government funded education program in order to create one out on my own proved successful, however now that the Santa Fe homeschool community has endorsed the program by sending their children to the classroom, we now need a bigger space with a private enclosed yard.  Students need physical activity to keep the brain open to learning.  We need to be able to run around and play a good round of Zombie Tag before we tackle long division!  Money will go towards moving expenses and new tables, chairs and shelves for a bigger space!


2. Art, Music and Soccer!

The Homeschool Classroom focuses on Math and Language Arts in the mornings, but afternoons are saved for more creative activities including Art, Music and Soccer!  We have hired some incredible artists, musicians and creative play and movement teachers to share their passion with the students.  We would like to be able to continue this practice paying talented, experienced children specialists to do a wide variety of projects with the kids.  Check out the photos/albums on our facebook page to see projects completed in the past! www.facebook.com/TheHomeschoolClassroom


3. Outdoor Lunch Space! 

The Homeschool Classroom students love the bed of my truck, in fact it has been the lunch table for the past 2 years! A proper picnic table is definitely in need.  We would like to develop an outdoor eating space complete with table, chairs and an outdoor recycling area.  


The Impact

Your contribution will directly improve the quality of life for kids at Ms. Cohen's Homeschool Classroom. We are a grassroots program, paving the way for alternative education in a nation of educational distress.  Help make a change for kids now.  Your donation will be used immediately.

Not only will your donation affect the lives and learning of The Homeschool Classroom students, but also your contribution is vote for your support of Alternative Education nationwide! Independent education of children is the growing trend as more and more children are unsatisfied with their current schooling experiences.  Be a part of this revolution and help students fall in love with learning again.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute financially, but want to help support alternative successful learning experiences for our children today:

like our page on facebook: www.facebook.com/TheHomeschoolClassroom

or share this campaign on Indiegogo or facebook

Thank-you!

~Ms. Rebecca Cohen

story:
The Harness Your Potential (HYP) Program is a supplement to the academic and extracurricular opportunities at New Orleans College Prep (NOCP) designed to enable our best and brightest 8th grade students to visit top college campuses over Spring Break.  Teachers not only preach the value of a college education, but expect each of our students to be admitted to a rigorous four year college or university. 

This year during the HYP program students will visit the campuses of Harvard and Georgetown Universities. This fundraising campaign is intended to cover the cost of flights for all students. Our goal may seem big, but every dollar makes a difference. $100 dollars covers the cost of a flight from Boston to DC for one scholar!

It is quite tough to strive for something that you have never seen. At NOCP, we serve at-risk students: 95% of our students are low-income, 14% have special needs, and 10% of all our students are homeless. For most of our students, this is their first opportunity to leave New Orleans, travel on an airplane, and set foot on a college campus.

Showing our students these universities will make the goal of a rigorous college education feel real and reachable.  The HYP Program is designed to instruct our scholars on exactly what they need to do to gain admission to these institutions and give them a sense of what it feels like to be a college student.

story:
Hello Friends/Alumni of ECE,


We hope that you are doing well wherever you are in the world.
Following an initiative from fellow alumni who are currently teaching at the department we are reaching out to you to support a noble cause. The ECE department has included in its revised curriculum new courses that require additional laboratory facility. Since the department does not have (enough of) them, it is difficult to deliver as much as needed. Although the university does not have a budget problem, any purchase is required to pass through a lengthy bidding process which often takes up to 2 years. Moreover, suppliers of such educational materials are not interested in bids. Currently the department faces problems for the courses: Embedded Systems, Robotics& Industrial Automation, Microcontrollers & Interfacing. So far, they have been using 15 STK500 micro controller kits donated in 2009 by alumni of the department. One of the items that they need for the coming academic year is the "Embedded Systems Education Board". (http://www.embeddedartists.com/products/education/edu_2148.php).

After an initiative from a faculty member and 2004 graduate,Getachew Teshome, a few alumni from year 2003 - 2007 met online to discuss on how we could meet this demand. Another faculty member and 2007 graduate,Daniel Dilbi, has already contacted a supplier who offered a 50% discount through a university program. After discussing and making researches, we have determined that a total of $5,000 is required to purchase and ship these boards to the department. We have thus opened an account for this purpose and we ask your kind contribution to meet our goal.
We will also be discussing in our next meetings on ways of creating an Alumni Network, which we will share with you as we progress. Your suggestions in this regard are very welcome.

Thank you,
AAU ECE Alumni Volunteer/Interim Group
