story:
Thanks for Stopping By!

We are a small group of law students and paralegals who all believe we can use our collective power to eradicate injustice by promoting equal access to and equal treatment within our legal system.

We have helped several families with our own funding, including subsidizing court filing fees, locating volunteer attorneys, providing legal forms and literature, counseling, referrals and much more. In order to expand our services to more states and help those in need, we ask for your valuable assistance in increasing funding. We are requesting statements from former and current clients be posted to Twitter & Facebook. These statements will give you a great idea about the positive impact we have provided to our clients.

Some of the matters we assist with are:

Juvenile Rights, Victims Rights, Veteran Rights, Consumer Rights, Family issues including child support and custody and housing matters.

What We Need & What You Get

Our team needs funds for transportation, client court fees, clinic location rentals and administrative help.  Every dollar goes a long way. We can run one clinic serving 15 clients for an average of $300 including location, speaker and literature/handouts. $100 can cover a volunteers transportation for 2 weeks, and/or provide low-income clients with 10 individual rides to clinics or meetings.

Our Victims/Survivors Project also accepts donations to assist families of violent crimes with legal and other related support and  referrals.

Why It Matters

If you have ever tried to obtain help in a legal matter, you know it can be a daunting process especially when income, education, disability or other restrictions pose additional obstacles. Public legal aid centers offer a wealth of assistance, but there are often waiting lists, income and asset restrictions and restrictions on the types of cases they accept.

We also recognize the sacrifice of firms and individuals offering pro bono services to low-income citizens, but depending on a clients location, these services are limited and there are simply not enough professionals able to support the needs of the community. We ensure that every individual eligible for our services receives high quality assistance and representation regardless of socio-economic status, gender, religion, age, ethnic background or sexual orientation.

 

What Else Can I Do?

If you are a passionate advocate who believes all citizens are entitled to equal access to the legal system, please inquire with us regarding seats on our Executive and Advisory boards and clerical and legal volunteer opportunities.

We also appreciate supply donations including printing paper (legal and letter), printer ink, report covers, legal pads and general office suppli

story:
Our Story

The mission of Human Accelerated Performance (HAP) is to increase both an individualâ€™s and a teamâ€™s competitive edge by improving their Social Emotional Intelligence (SEI).  HAPâ€™s professionals have over 100 years of experience in teaching SEI and it is our mission to increase an individualâ€™s personal and professional success by improving their SEI.  Our team consists of former professional athletes, academic practitioners, and doctors trained in SEI.

 

What is Social Emotional Intelligence?

â€œWe know that highly intelligent people can make terrible decisions. Their thinking may be driven by emotions of which they are only weakly aware or which they are unable to control or change" â€“ Max More, Ph.D.


 

SEI and Social Emotional Education (SEE) is the compilation of skills and practices that improve how people relate to their  own emotions and others.  Our use of SEI is to at-risk and underserved students and student-athletes with a practical toolkit which will assist them successfully navigate stressful and unfamiliar situations.  An individual's development of SEI is important for success at any grade level and provides at-risk and underserved students and student-athletes with the opportunity to consistently perform at their peak level both on and off the field.

The Impact

By reaching our goal, this campaign will allow Human Accelerated Performance to travel to public secondary schools and universities to install our data driven curriculum across the country.  Currently, many public secondary schools and universities don't understand how to better equip our young men and women socially and emotionally for life after school.  Less than 1% of public secondary school's in the U.S. have a curriculum in SEI or SEE.  The reality is that 99+% of student-athletes never make it to the professional level. Our curriculum provides social and emotional skills that has been proven to increase self-sufficiency, improve long term earning potential, resiliency and problem solving ability as well as decrease divorce rates, criminal activity, and suicide.

 

Schools are searching for answers, but don't know where to turn to.  Human Accelerated Performance has that answer, and we are prepared to help underserved and at-risk youth have a better chance at professional and personal success. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are currently looking for $50,000 which will be used for creating a SEI workbook for use in both public secondary schools (Junior High School and High School) and universities.  The campaign will also help Human Accelerated Performance in our outreach efforts to reach schools across the U.S. and especially in regions higher poverty levels.

 

If we don't reach our entire goal we will use the funds primarily to create the student workbook.  We will continue our outreach efforts, but will have to focus locally rather than taking the message to a regional level.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please get involved in your local communities and especially in your local public schools.  We should all have high expectations for our future generations, but in order to see those come to fruition, we must give them the support they deserve.  High expectations and high support are necessary for success.


Please spread the word of our campaign on Facebook, Twitter and with your family and friends.

Please get involved in your local communities and especially in your local public schools.  We should all have high expectations for our future generations, but in order to see those come to fruition, we must give them the support they deserve.  High expectations and high support are necessary for success.
Please spread the word of our campaign on Facebook, Twitter and with your family and friends.

story:
IMPACTO PROJECT

is dedicated to the empowerment

 of youths in third world countries through visual arts.

 

After a successful campaign for our Southeast Asia program in October 2010, 

we are EXCITED to announce that 

Impacto Project will be partnering with and teaching 

at an orphanage in PERU in the summer of 2011!!

 

Help us make this happen!

 NO DONATION AMOUNT IS TOO SMALL ($5, $10, $15)!

Any donation will help us reach our goal!

 

Where does the money go?

 

100% of the funds raised goes towards running the program from replacing broken cameras and getting new batteries, to supplying photo paper and printer ink, to securing rental spaces for a final exhibition of the students' works in their community.

 

Donate to our Winter 2010 fundraiser and we will express our thanks by sending you one of these awesome perks featuring original photographs taken by participants in the 2010 Panama & Myanmar (Burma) programs:

 

$50 - An 8" x 10" original color print

$20 - A full-color 2011 desk calendar & set of 5 notecards

$15 - A full-color 2011 desk calendar

$10 - A set of 5 notecards

 

Our programs depend mainly on individual donors like you.  Please spread the word to your friends, family, colleagues and strangers!  


Go to our Facebook page and follow our progress: 

www.facebook.com/impactoproject

 

Previous Impacto Project programs in Panama and Myanmar (Burma) have been highly successful. It is our privilege and mission to continue to bring the gift of visual arts to children around the world and we invite you to be part of it!

 

Happy holidays and thanks in advance,

Anayansi Prado & Elease Lui
Co-founders, Impacto Project

 

P.S. We are also accepting donations of used (or new) point and shoot digital cameras.
Please send cameras to:


Elease Lui
3371 Cahuenga Blvd West
Los Angeles, CA 90068

story:
Meet Royal Basketball Academy

My name is Coach K. I am the Director of Royal Basketball Academy (RBA). RBA is a youth organization that uses basketball as a tool for character development. Now in our second year, RBA is expanding from one team in one school to eight teams in three schools located in Harlem, the Bronx, and Queens. Our programming includes basketball fundamentals, academic enrichment, homework help, character development workshops, and community service projects. RBA's programming is especially designed to serve NYC's young inner-city boys. 

RBA suddenly had our funding cut . . .

Unfortunately, RBA recently had our funding cut. This is an all too familiar scenario in education and youth development organizations. Funding now, during this critical juncture can help RBA not only continue funding this year, but can help bridge us to sustainability.

 

Through our program this year, RBA is providing programming for 96 young people and part-time employment for six coaches. RBA's contributions are critical for the young people we serve. Our anger management programming helps create safe school communities. Our homework help programming helps create a culture of homework completion. Our community service projects help create a culture of giving back. Most importantly, RBA develops mentorship relationships and an intergenerational mentorship community.

What We Need

RBA already has receives funding from several sources. Our partnership schools make significant contributions. We receive small monetary donation from local businesses and a small grant from a foundation. Although our program is provided at no cost to parents, RBA will also receive funding from parents and the school community through innovative fundraising programs.

 

With all of these funding sources pitching in, we are still short of our budget. Your contributions will help bridge the gap towards sustainability. RBA's work is more in-depth than many youth organizations. We are creating mentorship relationships with young people as a much-needed level of accountability. You are donating to New York City's young people being able to say, "That's My Coach," and it mean more than just basketball. Within RBA, Coach means someone who participates in workshops and community service projects, someone who can speak to your parents and advocate on your behalf, someone who pushes you to be excellent both on and off the court.

 

Specifically, your donations will go to basketball equipment, league fees, educational supplies, basic media equipment (for youth who participate on our media team), travel expenses, stipends for coaches, and healthy snacks.

We Need Your Help

In addition to providing monetary donations, you can also help spread the word. Do you know someone passionate about basketball and education? Do you know someone who is always complaining about the need for professional athletes to be more socially responsible? Send this link through Facebook and Twitter to share a glimpse in the potential for using youth athletics as a tool for character development.

story:
A Short Story of Me...

It's been years that I learned some people are not born lucky. 
So I drawed my path in life to stand strong but sometimes things are not clear sailing o.O

After working years in a company which idenfies itself as one of the biggest corporation in its sector, I faced with being not paid my salary and then unemployed... (the judicial process still continues like it will never ever end!)
After all those hard days, there came new problems about my financial situation...
During those days, I applied for my master to an instutide in Istanbul for studying human resources and organizational change with expecting I could get my money from the company with the dijudication, but it didn't happened...

And guess what? I got a call from the school and they said I was accepted for masters study...

Usually we human beings get happy when we hear a good news, especially if it is about ourselves...
But what I felt when I heard the good news was the pain in my stomach about how I could afford the cost of my study...
And in seconds, worrying if I can't pay for my study I would miss the chance which I cannot get a second time was the next thing I thought...

Anyway, short story long, I need your support!

1 $ or 1 pence... doesn't matter how much you can...

Please consider what I ask for, more like a support to a young man who tries to reach his dreams...

Love to all who cares or who doesn't...

Kagan.

story:
Short Summary

We are a group of concerned parents that have joined forces with the Ashkenazi community in Mexico City to provide kindergarten education and after-school programs to help reverse the trend of jewish discontinuity, which is especially present among Ashkenazi Jews in Mexico.


After most Mexican Jews left the downtown area of Mexico City to find more space in the suburbs, all the Jewish education centers moved there with them, leaving the downtown area unattended. Recently, there's been a trend to move back to the urban areas, both to reduce our cost of living and  to lead a more urban lifestyle.

All the Jewish families that live in this area don't have access to Jewish education unless they put their children on a hour-long bus ride. Having access to a Jewish kindertgarten provides the roots and foundation towards leading a Jewish younghood and adulthood. Our long-term goal is to provide high-quality services for this neighborhood to be a viable option for jews to return to in order to revive and strengthen this jewish community!

We have successfully culminated our first school  year at the Gan thanks to the help of our many incredible donors during our previous campaign  and went from having 4  to 10 students and we are expecting at least 8 more to join before the end of the current school year. 

What We Need & What You Get

We finished building the school last summer, we were able to purchase all the initial material for all ages  thanks to all our incredibly generous donors and the continued support of the Ashkenazi Community in Mexico City, to whom we are eternally grateful. This year we will become self-sustainable and we are asking for your help to raise scholarship funds and to make some needed safety and security enhancements on the space. 
 

Your contribution will help us:

  • Create a scholarship fund to help the children of needed jewish families at our neighborhood have a jewish education at our Gan
  • Install a retractible roof to guard the play area against sun and rain
  • Change the Gan's entrance doors - since the ones that were there originally were built to be safe enough to guard children.  
  • Continue adding material for the school's library

The Impact

We know of at least 70 young jewish families which are living in the downtown area of Mexico City. Most of which end up moving back to the suburbs due to lack of jewish educational centers downtown. Moving to the suburbs means having a higher cost of living and giving up on the urban lifestyle which we want our kids to grow up in including having access to public parks and recreation centers, playing outside, knowing all kinds of people, experiencing social and environmental responsibility first-hand, among others.


Like the old saying goes “build it and they will come” we strongly believe that once these educational services will help bring a return to judaism among the families that are and will live here, strengthening the community and moving it away from discontinuity of our religion.

This educational center has the following services:

  • Regular kindergarten education for children from 1-6 years of age.
    • Our education is montessori  - allowing children to explore and use their initiative and natural abilities to learn through practical play.
    • We motivate our kids to grow independent and curious minds
    • We build the identity of our children with both jewish and mexican traditions
  • Extended hours to help working parents from 1 p.m. to 3 p.m.
  • After-school classes (art, music, dance, early stimulation)
  • Free afterschool hebrew and judaism classes and family activities
  • Judaism and child-rearing educational seminars for parents

Other Ways You Can Help

We are looking for contributions in-kind as well, if you know where we can get lightly-used material, books, furniture, etc. we will be forever in debt.

You can also contribute by sharing this with everyone you know

Finally, if you live in Mexico City and are interested in working with us full time or want to volunteer to teach one of the after-school programs please contact us.

To read more about our program please visit www.gancondesa.com

Thank you very much!

story:
Be a part of a drug-free approach to helping children improve their ability to learn academically, socially and emotionally. Make a difference today!

Thank you for taking the time to visit our Learning for Success campaign to raise funds to open a Brain Balance Center in Southern New Jersey to help children with learning and behavioral issues become successful. We need your help with being a part of the solution to making the lives of children suffering from ADHD, Asperger and other learning and/or behavioral disorders much improved.

Brain Balance centers are the cutting-edge, drug-free approach to help children improve their ability to learn academically, socially and emotionally. The goal is to not just work with a child’s strengths or compensate for a weakness but to also confront a child’s issues head on, by addressing the root cause at the most fundamental level. This center will help kids with ADHD, Asperger, learning disorders, behavior issues, processing disorders and PPD-NOS.

                                    


The research team of the Brain Balance Centers is grounded in decades of published research by renowned scientists and professionals from around the world. The program instituted are the most comprehensive approach to overcoming the symptoms of ADHD, learning disabilities, processing disorders, Asperger syndrome, and a host of other related childhood learning and developmental issues. The approach of the center would be to utilize an integrated cutting edge approach that combines three core modalities into one program. This has been proven to lead to the most effective, lasting results while saving time and minimizing stress for a parent and a child. After the results of a child’s individualized assessment, a program tailored specifically to the child’s unique needs will be created that will eventually play an important role in improving a child’s ability to learn and behave at an age-appropriate level. By supporting the funding of this center, you help kids who would normally be prescribed dangerous medications, placed in educational environments that do more harm than good, or become under achievers in a very competitive world.

                           

Thank you for taking the time to read this campaign and if you have any questions please ask.

WHERE WILL THE MONEY BE USED

We are seeking to raise $75,000 to make the LEARNING FOR SUCCESS project  successful, and right now EVERY DOLLAR YOU CONTRIBUTE is very important. Your contribution will be used to execute a Brain Balance Center franchise agreement, secure a location, and begin the development/construction of the center and finally the completion and opening of the center.

                                   


HOW CAN YOU CONTRIBUTE

·  $10: Supporter package

For anyone donating $10 and above, you will receive a copy of the brochure for our Brain Balance Center when it is. (Ships within the US only)

·  $50:Supporter package

You want to show you are willing to put real skin in the game. For anyone donating $50 and above, you will have the option of being appreciated and listed as supporters of the project website once created. (Ships within the US only)

·  $250:Supporter package

All of the opportunities mentioned above and participation in a Live Chat with others and outlining the research and the drug free treatments provided by the center. (Ships within the US only)

·  $1,000:Supporter package

All of the opportunities mentioned above and invitation to the grand opening party at the facility. $100 transferable Voucher that can be applied to center services.

·  $2,500:Supporter package

All of the above and if desired a web link associated with your name or organization, on the center website once created. Additional $100 transferable Voucher that can be applied to center services.

                           


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you cannot contribute you can still help by getting the word out. Make friends and family aware of this project and tell them to spread the word as well. The share tools are accessible for your convenience. Therefore we are running a referral competition in which the person who raises the most awareness of the crowdfunding campaign and gets the most people to visit this Indigogo page will win a dinner for two at any restaurant of your choice and two front row tickets to a show or concert of your choice, if the campaign is funded.

If you don't have an Indigogo account, go and register one by clicking up top. When you are finished, come back to this page. At the top of this page use the share buttons to share this campaign with others. You can use the social media buttons, but also the Link button to generate your unique web link that points to this page. This link helps us to ensure we register that you referred the person to this page. Be sure to use these links...they include the information needed for us to register your referrals!

  1. Each time you share the campaign with these links we will track them in a running tally. We will regularly update everyone with the current rankings each week in our campaign updates.
Importantly, we are awarding the prize to the person who gets the most people visiting this page, so try to spread the word as far and wide as you can! 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES


The challenges for this project would be obtaining an executing the franchise agreement. Also finding a perfect location for the facility in an area that would truly benefit from this center. Once the location is secured, there could be challenges with the construction of the facility that would delay the project such as weather, permits. Any delay would not take more than several months.

Zion Baseball Academy is Christian based non profit organization created to provide affordable detailed baseball instructions in a controlled environment.

Passion

Family


All kids from 6-15 are welcome, regardless of financial ability. Your money will go toward providing baseball supplies and leasing baseball fields for clinics and tournaments.

story:
#30Days of ThanksgivingLO  

You may not know this about me, but I had the AMAZING opportunity to go through a program called Legal Outreach in high school. Legal Outreach works with students from underserved neighborhoods around NYC and prepares them to succeed in high school, college, and beyond.  

I'm fundraising this November to make it possible for more students like me to go through Legal Outreach.  

My Story  

My name is Umme Lena and I grew up in Queens. I went to Bayside High School. 

Because of Legal Outreach, I was encouraged to apply to colleges and attended Mt. Holyoke. My options were limited to city colleges (CUNY), since there was a necessity to commute back and forth from home to school. Because of my parents' disapproval towards applying for out-of-state colleges/universities, I could not consider anything past city colleges around my neighborhood. 

Ms. Bethsheba Cooper encouraged me to look beyond these college and consider out-of-state colleges. She believed in me and the potential I possessed to get accepted to one of the top 50 colleges. I stepped out of bounds and build strength and determination to apply for private, out-of-state colleges, taking advantage of the College prep workshop. The Saturday Writing Classes helped in forming personal statements and short answers for college applications. 

The support I received from Ms. Cooper and other faculty members in LO made it much easier for me, unlike for my peers in high school. In return, I helped my friends with their college applications and personal statements. In addition, college tuition was highly discouraging, but through LO's guidance, it became possible with their help in financial aid applications and through LO's scholarship, accumulated within the four years in LO. 

After getting accepted to Mount Holyoke College, I opened a pathway to prove to my parents that I was capable and I deserved this educational opportunity after working hard and diligently throughout my high school years. I cannot ever be grateful enough to Ms. Cooper who gave me the extra push to even apply to colleges outside of my neighborhood and stand up for my right to the best education I can receive. I am also thankful to Mr. O'Neal, Mr. Santana, and many more amazing faculty members that have emotionally, financially, and academically supported me in my endeavor. I am here, as a Mount Holyoke student, because of them. 

Your support can change the lives of more students like me!

              

Your Support Will... 

Make it possible for more students like me to go through Legal Outreach for four years of free programming, including a debate program, SAT prep, writing classes, mentoring, college application workshops, and much more! 

Of the students LO supports: 

  • 100% graduated HS on time (only 66% of NYC public school students do) 
  • 99% went on to colleges and universities 

Other Ways You Can Help 

  • Donate to my campaign before December 2nd, 2014 
  • Share my campaign on social media 
  • Encourage your networks to support my campaign 

I'm thankful for LO and I'm thankful for your support!  

#30DaysofThanksgivingLO
www.legaloutreach.org
www.facebook.com/legaloutreach
@legaloutreach

#30Days of ThanksgivingLO  You may not know this about me, but I had the AMAZING opportunity to go through a program called Legal Outreach in high school. Legal Outreach works with students from underserved neighborhoods around NYC and prepares them to succeed in high school, college, and beyond.  I'm fundraising this November to make it possible for more students like me to go through Legal Outreach.  My Story  My name is Umme Lena and I grew up in Queens. I went to Bayside High School. Because of Legal Outreach, I was encouraged to apply to colleges and attended Mt. Holyoke. My options were limited to city colleges (CUNY), since there was a necessity to commute back and forth from home to school. Because of my parents' disapproval towards applying for out-of-state colleges/universities, I could not consider anything past city colleges around my neighborhood. Ms. Bethsheba Cooper encouraged me to look beyond these college and consider out-of-state colleges. She believed in me and the potential I possessed to get accepted to one of the top 50 colleges. I stepped out of bounds and build strength and determination to apply for private, out-of-state colleges, taking advantage of the College prep workshop. The Saturday Writing Classes helped in forming personal statements and short answers for college applications. The support I received from Ms. Cooper and other faculty members in LO made it much easier for me, unlike for my peers in high school. In return, I helped my friends with their college applications and personal statements. In addition, college tuition was highly discouraging, but through LO's guidance, it became possible with their help in financial aid applications and through LO's scholarship, accumulated within the four years in LO. After getting accepted to Mount Holyoke College, I opened a pathway to prove to my parents that I was capable and I deserved this educational opportunity after working hard and diligently throughout my high school years. I cannot ever be grateful enough to Ms. Cooper who gave me the extra push to even apply to colleges outside of my neighborhood and stand up for my right to the best education I can receive. 100% graduated HS on time (only 66% of NYC public school students do) 
99% went on to colleges and universities

Encourage your networks to support my campaign

story:
• Short Summary

I am the grandfather of 4, a college graduate, veteran, and business owner.  My business failed and I find myself living solely on social security.  More than 15 years ago, I wrote what I consider to be a classic children's story.  It is the definitive alphabet story which promotes literacy by encouraging children's personal love for letters and numbers.  The story is titled, THE A's WERE FIRST TO GO.

The thing I like most and that for which I am most proud, is that it is a clever story which does not talk down to children.  The story is quite unique when compared to typical children's books.  For one example, it is more than 30 pages long.  We take a simple concept and let it progress to its  logical (?? :-) conclusion.  This particular journey requires 3 chapters and more than 30 pages to get the conclusion.  Happily,  children love the long adventure.  

This whimsical, humorous story is about the time when all the letters and numbers left.  It is a mystery.  No one knew where they had gone or why the left.  The story is great for very young child (ages 4 to 6) who love to have a parent or grandparent read to them.  It is also great for those a little older (ages 6 to 9) who like to read for themselves.   

Teacher, librarians, parents, grandparents, and small children love the story. Everyone encouraged me to get the story published.  Therefore, I ventured forth - as I am sure you would have.  Unfortunately, it is almost impossible for one who is not published to become one who is published.  Over the years I accumulated many, many rejection letters from traditional publishers.

I tried as hard and as often as I could to get published.  Against the advice of 'experts', I even spent more than $5000 for rough, black and white illustrations that attempt to graphically convey the whimsy and humor in the story.  I hoped the draft illustrations would improve my chances of getting published.  It didn’t work. 

Please go to our 'Gallery' tab - above- to get a little flavor of the story.

I have not given up on the story but I have given up on the hope of finding a traditional publisher to put it together.  The time is late for me and I realize my only recourse is to self-publish, but the cost is more than I can handle today.

If I had the resources, the first thing I would do is refine and colorize the illustrations and the cover.  Obviously, they are in rough draft form and need to be upgraded.  This alone would cost several thousand dollars.  Then I would have a vanity publisher put the book together.  I would then buy as many of the finished books as finances allow and embark on a marketing and promotional program. 

The program would include attending book fairs, sending copies to buyers across the country who purchase for county-wide school library systems, picking the brains of other self-publishers who found success, reading to children in libraries and book stores, etc., etc., etc.  My goal would be to demonstrate the value and popularity of the book, in the hope that a traditional publisher would pick it up and make it readily available to every child, parent, and grandparent in the country.

Actively doing something tangible that encourages thousands of children to love letters and number is a noble endeavor, one that can provide satisfaction almost beyond description.  As the author of a book that can inspire thousands of children to have a greater regard for literacy, I can honestly say my dream will not happen without your help.  This is an opportunity for you, personally, to partake in that noble endeavor and make it partly your dream too. 

If you know others who might want to help bring about a quality children's book that promotes literacy, either for their own families, or for all children in general, please refer them to this campaign.

Please contribute whatever you can.

story:
Update: check out what our scholars have been up to since we launched the campaign!


Who we are

The United World Colleges (UWCs) are fourteen boarding schools around the world that share a common aim: to educate and inspire high school students to create a more peaceful and sustainable future. The schools provide a rigorous academic program and have a strong commitment to community service. They are non-denominational and attract a diverse student body, most of whom attend with scholarship support. Many UWC graduates move on to University on scholarships. Read more about UWC here.

Why Sudan?

We are the Sudan selection committee for UWC and we share a commitment to help this country. After decades of civil war and the secession of South Sudan in 2011, many areas of the country (including Darfur and the Nuba Mountains) are still in conflict. Economic conditions in Sudan have also deteriorated sharply in the past three years, including spiralling inflation and devaluation rates.

Sudan also hosts the largest population of Eritrean refugees in the world. Since 2013, the selection process is open to applications from refugee students living in Sudan, most of which are Eritreans. The vast majority of young Eritrean refugees have no hope of continuing their Higher Education in Sudan.

We believe that educating Sudanese and Eritrean young people in peace and international understanding will help make the future of Sudan, Eritrea and this region brighter. 

We have sent 11 students to UWC in the past 3 years

In 2012, we sent our first ever scholar to UWC: Razan Idris, a bright young student from Ombdurman, who attended a UWC in the United States. Razan has now graduated and started her first year at Duke University, having been awarded one of only seven Reginaldo Howard Memorial Scholarships.

In 2013, over 200 candidates applied for the scholarship program, and we selected four excellent students who are currently in their second year at UWCs in India, Italy, the Netherlands and Costa Rica. In 2014, we received close to 300 applications and selected six students who are now in their first year at UWCs in India, Canada, the Netherlands, Armenia, Norway and Costa Rica. 

Your donation contributes to peace

Academically bright, empathetic and creative, we are certain these 16 and 17 year olds are the future of this region. You can learn more about them in our gallery or on our website.

Here is what Razan has to say about her time at UWC: “Coming to UWC, I realized just how much being Sudanese meant to me, and how much I love Sudan. Sometimes living in Sudan you only see its shortcomings. Yet here at UWC I became prouder of my heritage, and I saw that in my hands lay the power to change so many people's ideas of Sudan, with the truth that I had lived.”

UWC tuition & board scholarships are each worth about $65,000. Eight of our scholars have attended on full scholarships and three on partial scholarships. We need your help with two things.

1. Help get our scholars to their colleges

Students on full scholarship need funds to cover additional costs such as flights, visa fees, pocket money and health insurance. Each scholar has slightly different funding requirements, and we are in regular contact with their families to assess financial need. We then work with the student's colleges to disburse funds according to need. Any left over funds are kept to cover similar expenses for future scholars.

In 2013, we ran a successful crowdfunding campaign to cover expenses for our scholars. You can see it here. Cani Fajak, one of the beneficiaries of this campaign, is enjoying her time in Italy, but that’s a long way from home. A flight to Sudan once per year has meant she shares the experience with friends and family. Mohammed Humed, another of the scholars, went from a refugee camp in eastern Sudan to the Netherlands. Aside from ensuring he secured a visa even though he doesn't have a passport, the funds have also paid for him to get some good winter clothes!

We calculate it will take $20,000 to cover the expenses of all our 2014 - 2016 and 2015 - 2017 scholars. Donating today will mean our current and future scholars continue to benefit from a needs-based expenses fund.

2. Help complete a partial scholarship

Together with the Colleges and local donors, we have managed to fundraise 4 full scholarships and 2 partial scholarships for the next academic year (2015 - 2017). From experience in the past three years, we know that finding scholars whose families have the means to complete a partial scholarship can be challenging. In the past years, we have lost a number of partial scholarships because of this.

It takes about $30,000 to complete a partial scholarship. Donating today will mean we can send one more Sudanese or refugee student to participate in a life-changing educational experience.

In the detail: where your donations go

The UWC Sudan Selection Committee is run exclusively by volunteers, both Sudanese and international, and will not keep any fees. All the funds collected will go to:

(i) The Colleges. They will make the entirety of the funds available to our scholars for their expenses.

(ii) Administration Costs charged by Indiegogo. This will be no more than 9% of raised funds.

Funds are collected by the UWC International Office on our behalf. But don't worry, your funds will reach us! The International Office of the UWC organisation, based in London, will receive and channel the funds to each scholar’s College. 

Colleges help our Scholars manage their expenses.  All expense funds are allocated to scholars on the basis of demonstrated need. The college pastoral care staff then give funds directly to the scholars for their needs. Sometimes, college staff will help our scholars make larger purchases, such as plane tickets.

Funds for a partial scholarship will be sent to the relevant college. We will work with the college to ensure funds to complete a partial scholarship reach the college directly. Our scholars will not need to manage this, in their eyes they will have a full scholarship!

Expenses take precedence over the partial scholarship. If we don't reach our fundraising goal, then we will first cover the expenses of students who have already received a full scholarship. We will consider adding to a partial scholarship only after these expenses are fully met. In any case, your donation will always contribute directly to a Sudanese or refugee student receiving a  transformative education geared towards international understanding, global citizenship and peace.

How you can help 

1. Make a donation. The good news is that we’ve done most of the fundraising already! We have raised four full scholarships and two partial scholarships. For scholar expenses, a donation of $100 could make all the difference. In fact, if 200 people give $100 each, we will cover all scholar expenses through 2017!

2. Make your donation as a gift to someone else. We will send them a personalised greeting card featuring photos of our Scholars, and letting them know that a donation was made on their behalf. Cards can be sent by post or email. As soon as your donation is made, we will contact you via email to gather the contact details of the gift recipient. To see a sample of a card, go to our gallery.

3. Spread the word. If this isn’t the right time for you to give money, you can still support the UWC Sudan scholars by telling your friends about this campaign. Just emailing this video to 10 friends, reposting on your Facebook page, or Tweeting about it could make a significant difference.

We really appreciate your support and look forward to sharing with you the adventures of our scholars at the United World Colleges.

story:
Short Summary

Griot Sway is a hot new rap by kids that celebrates African American heritage and culture. We've made the song and now we're making the music video and premiering it at our music video release party where the kids will perform Griot Sway live!

Why?

  • Because kids want to rap words that make them proud of their heritage
  • Because parents don't want their kids repeating the raps on the radio
  • Because kids and parents should be able to rap together, nod their heads together and dance together while celebrating African American culture.

    Here's a look at production stills and a few video clips from the audition through the shoot.

    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B-dDdF3mcGk

    What We Need

    With 4 rappers and 26 dancers and actors, it costs money to make our production fantastic.

    We want the video to look great so we hired professionals - a cinematographer, an editor, make up artists and wardrobe professionals.

    To cover the cost of a little red carpet, cup cakes and hot wings in the VIP section at our music video release party.

    We should mention, we also had one of Beyonce's choreographers work as our choreographer. We'd like to thank him with a gift.

    What You Get

    For $1 you get access to the music. You can listen to it online unlimited or for another dollar, you can download it and rock out with your friends and family in the car, at school or at work.

    If you can give more, we'd appreciate it. If not, no sweat. Just help us spread the word.

    The Big Picture

    Since we're only asking for $1 and are giving away such a great perk, we realize this might go viral so, we're going to lay out our big picture or stretch goals now:
     
    $2500 and the kids get paid!
    Yes, if you think the hard working rappers, actors and dancers involved in this project should get paid, help us exceed our goal and make it to $2500.

    $5000 and we make another song!
    If you love the song, and want to help us exceed our goal and hit $5000, the kids will get paid and we'll make another song and everyone who donated to this campaign, will get it for FREE.

    $10,000 and we make a short film, starring kids!
    If you love the work we're doing and want to help us exceed our goal and hit $10,000 we'll make a short film and everyone who donated  to this campaign, will get a sneak peak for FREE.

    Strategy

    If you've read this far, you're officially on our team!

    We're asking all team members to send an email to everyone you know who celebrates African American culture, youth, hip hop, rap, education and positivity and ask them to donate $1 or more.

    "It takes a village to raise a campaign goal"
    Thank you for your support!

    GriotWorks connects people around the world to relevant themes in Black culture. We collect, document and share stories through mixed media storytelling, discussions and social media. Our work sharpens audiences ability to critique, analyze and challenge mainstream media through the power of story.

    GriotWorks is a program of CultureTrust Greater Philadelphia, which operates under the fiscal stewardship of CultureWorks Greater Philadelphia. CultureTrust provides a charitable home and affordable shared management resources for arts and heritage programs of diverse disciplines and cultural traditions.

story:
My name is Massimo Canevacci. I'm professor of Cultural Anthropology at the Faculty of Sciences of Communication, University of Rome "La Sapienza" - Now I'm Visiting  Professor at the Institute of Advanced Studies  in the University of São Paulo (IEA-USP, Brazil).

Since 1995, my fieldwork is Bororo culture  at Meruri and Garças villages (Mato Grosso, Brazil). José Carlos Kuguri, the last Bororo mestre dos cantos  passed away on the June 20, 2014. To honor his death, this project aims to collect funds towards the realization of the most important cosmological ritual of their culture: the Bororo Funeral. 

The ritual of the funeral is connected to their philosophy, according to which the master of songs plays a central role through the whole process. The ritual begins with the inhumation of the body of the deceased, followed by his/her exhumation and the transfiguration of his/her skull and bones into an ancestral being (arara). The body of José Carlos was already buried at the center of his aldeia (Garças) at the end of this June. Since then, his body has been watered everyday to facilitate putrefaction until his exhumation, which should take place at the beginning of this October. By then, the most important phase of the Bororo ritual will take place.

Donations may favor the realization not only of the funeral, but of the self-representation project: Beyond the Salesians, Fazendeiros or Rede Globo influences, Bororo culture must survive. The realization of this funeral is crucial to the Bororo people in that it enables them to reproduce their political stance in the world through their practices of autonomous self-representation. As such, it is part and parcel of contemporary human heritage, hence important to everybody else living everywhere in the world. 

I'd like to receive 2.500 US$: it is necessary to fund expenses concerning the arrival and stay of other masters of songs and the participation of other Bororo representatives from several other aldeias in Mato Grosso, who will be also in charge of nominating a successor to José Carlos.

story:
Short Summary

ZackPack Promotions Inc. was started to bring awareness and funding to causes that are close to my heart and have greatly affected me as well as my family. Autism is one of these causes. I am the mother of a beautiful 10 year old little girl who was diagnosed with Autism at the age of 3.

“Bustin’ for Autism” is an event that brings in talent, vendors, and other wonderful people to help support and promote awareness for the cause. The event is similar to a Comic-Con, but on a much smaller scale. The main goal for the event is to raise enough funds to be able to sponsor Special Needs Children directly and send them to Special Needs Camps. We also donate to other non-profits that help the community

What We Need & What You Get

While the Talent we have mostly donates their time, we still need to arrange for transportation and accommodations while attending the event. Any additional funds over the goal we are asking for will go directly to the cause that “Bustin’ for Autism” supports. If we do not make our goal, we will use what we have received on the monetary expenses to make the event happen!


The Impact

“Bustin’ for Autism” is exactly that. We are Bustin’ are butts for Children with Autism.

Why Special Needs Camps? We want to start shedding light on the positivity and fun that these camps provide for the children, the social environment that is required for them to thrive and the special people who have the gift to interact in a positive, yet knowledgeable, way with our children.

This is the Second“Bustin’ for Autism” event we are doing. The last one we did was very nice and we were able to sponsor one child. We were also able to sponsor the JJWATT Foundation, a non-profit organization that helps children in school and Wrestlecade, a charity for Children’s Christmas Toy drive.


Risks & Challenges

We try very diligently to shed light on positive things, and not bring up anything rotten. Like everyone else, we have our share of doubters. Even more the reason we keep moving on. Our hope is that we are able put smiles on the faces of these beautiful children, like the one you see in the photo, because that's what matters to us.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate, that’s ok. Awareness of what we do works too. Please, share our link and our Facebook page. Let’s get the word out!

story:
Short Summary

We need your help to build a Rain Water Garden at Fox Haven Organic Farm and Learning Center. The garden will be planted with native flowers, shrubs, and trees that will provide valuable habitat for birds, butterflies, and other pollinators. Including plants like milk weed to help support a struggling Monarch butterfly population.

We try to make everything we do a learning opportunity, building this garden will give us an opportunity to showcase a sustainable way to work with rain water run off, teach how rainwater gardens work, as well as how we work to reclaim our water and protect the local creeks and water ways that lead into the Potomac River and eventually the Chesapeake Bay.

As we have begun the summer season in our newly re-designed Common Garden, a large amount of water run off has been washing out part of the hill side and causing problems for (our awesome!) Farm team and Garden manager. This beautiful garden is used as a demonstration organic garden to teach people of all ages organic growing techniques, the importance of growing your own food, and how easy (and fun!) it can be to buy food from your local farmer. We use the garden for children's summer programs and adult Farm Kitchen Dinners. Excess veggies are given to local food banks and shelters. Unfortunately, areas at the bottom of the Common Garden have become unusable due to boggy conditions. With YOUR help we can install a permaculturally designed rainwater catchment garden. 

That means in addition to preventing boggy conditions in our educational garden, the rain garden will prevent stream erosion and flooding by slowing rainwater runoff. This creates a natural filtration area that recharges the groundwater supply,  protects the creeks and water ways from silt and contamination as well as creates a sustainable example of mindful land preservation.

What We Need & What You Get

We need supplementary funds to be able to get the best materials and support our teachers!

what do you get?

  • Our love and appreciation!
  • Donations are tax deductable.
  • The knowledge that you helped support an environmentally focused project that will be used as a teaching device in the future.
  • A personalized post card from the building of the garden.
  • Gift certificates.
  • Seed packets.
  • Your name on a donor sign.
  • A book of beautiful photographs documenting the project.
  • A private Farm to table dinner for you and your friends/family.

The Impact

Rain water gardens are created to slow water and filter sediment, pollutants, and nutrients before runoff meets ground water or the creek, protecting our waterways and drinking water. At Fox Haven this rain garden will slow and cleanse the water before reaching the Lewis Mill Creek below, a tributary to Catoctin Creek which flows into the Potomac River. Additionally, this garden will protect our hillside and keep the Common Garden from flooding.  Together we will create another example of working with the land in a healthy way! 

The rain garden will be part of our tours for school groups, sustainability professionals, garden groups, farm visitors and people of all ages! Please help us create a more sustainable future by modelling what can be done. Your contributions will not only effect the health and well-being of our site and local waterways, but will help create a foundation of leading by example! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign to help us get the word out about Fox Haven and our projects! 

Join the newsletter (there is a link below) to learn about upcoming workshops and events such as Garden-to-Kitchen Dinners, Barn Dances, or Children's Programs at Fox Haven Organic Farm and Learning Center!

story:
My name is Sadie Stephens. I'm about to start my first semester of college, and hope to be the first member of my immediate family to graduate from a four-year college in the spring of 2018, and from there go on to become a high school biology teacher, or maybe even try for graduate school. To even begin to do those things, I need a head-start on textbooks. My rent takes up almost 41% of my paycheck before taxes each month, and there is not enough left over to cover utilities, groceries, and textbooks for my first semester of college. By helping me to pay for my textbooks, you are offering me the chance at an education that I would not be able to afford otherwise. 

         The average cost of college textbooks per semester is $561. I added on the extra $9 just in case the average is lower than what it will actually cost me. All of the money from this campaign will go directly to covering the cost of my textbooks, and any extra will go toward the cost of my textbooks for my second semester of college. If I don't reach my goal of $570, whatever is there will still go toward the cost of my textbooks. If, for some reason, I make more than I need for my textbooks throughout college, the remainder will go toward another student's college textbooks. In return, every single person who donates will get something reflecting the amount of their donation: for the smaller donations, a handwritten thank-you note; for the medium donations, a small hand-knit critter (please let me know if you have allergies); for the larger donations, a hand-knit hat, pair of gloves, or (knit) critter with pictures of it strolling around my hometown. I can also write your name on my face for a day and send you pictures. That goes for any donations. Just ask. 
           By covering the cost of my textbooks, you all are helping me to graduate from college without incurring massive amounts (or at least, more massive) of debt that I would never be able to get away from. It also allows me to continue paying rent and buying groceries during my time at college. After I graduate, not having to worry so much about paying off student loans as a teacher will allow me to devote more time and energy to my future students, and hopefully inspire a new generation of children to become scientists and scholars, like I was by my teachers. 
             Getting through college is not going to be easy. I am registered for 12 (15 if I manage to get off of the waiting list to one class) credit hours this semester, and am working a part-time job that begins ten minutes after my classes end. I expect to have several hours of homework every night that I have class, which leaves very little time for me to spend caring for myself and with my friends. They're in college, too, though, so they understand. I know that I can get through this. I have been looking forward to college since I was in kindergarten, and now that it's almost time to begin, I keep finding myself so excited that I'm practically buzzing. I plan on completing my homework and my studying in the student library at AB Tech after work each day, as well as checking up on my online classes. In two years, I hope to have my associate's degree and from there I plan on transferring to UNCA to major in biology and complete the grades 9-12 teaching licensure. Having a head-start on my textbooks is going to make a huge difference for me. 
             If you can't contribute, that is okay. But, if you would please, please share this page with as many people as you can, I would greatly appreciate it. There are buttons on the side of the page to make it easier to share this on the various social media platforms. Probably not on tumblr, but that would be cool. We once managed to get someone a chicken on tumblr. A living one, of course. It was fluffy and white and really neat-looking.

story:
Harriet Tubman Students Need Your Support

Harriet Tubman Democratic High School is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit school serving mostly low-income families in and around Albany, NY. Harriet Tubman enrolls many students who were drop-outs or considered at-risk, and offers a safe and diverse community for all youth. We receive no public funds and have always run on the principle that all youth deserve equal educational  opportunities — no one has ever been turned away based on economic considerations.  Over half of our students have always received scholarships. For the past three school years, over 90% of our students received significant tuition assistance, with over 70% qualifying for full tuition coverage. This is why we are turning to you for help. 


Students need our services, but we are struggling to provide them because we lack the funding. Every year our students, staff, parents, board, and volunteers work hard to raise the money needed to sponsor every child-in-need. We are halfway through the school year and must raise an additional $21,000 by July 1, 2015. The $5,000 goal of this Indiegogo campaign will allow us to reach our incremental goal this quarter.

You Can Help These Children Graduate

With your support, we can continue to serve children in desperate need of our help. 79% of Harriet Tubman graduates have gone on to attend college or career training programs and 97% have been successful there. The unique philosophy of the Harriet Tubman program allows us to meet the particular challenges children face and helps them earn a high school diploma.

Over eight years ago, Harriet Tubman Democratic High School opened its doors to offer students a learning environment that responds to the unique needs of each child. Our student-centered school engages every child in their own learning process with the guidance and support of teachers dedicated to their academic and personal development. Visit here for a detailed presentation of our program.

You Will be Helping Children Like...

Sakeem first came to Harriet Tubman as a 17 year old 9th grader, having dropped out after failing multiple times. Sakeem was extremely self-conscious about his age and lacked the confidence needed to succeed academically. His common  refrain: “I can’t do it.” 

 

Yet Sakeem had a passionate desire to earn his high school diploma, and the staff recognized this. They committed their time to building a trusting relationship with him, and provided the mentorship and individual instruction he needed.  Through the safe and supportive community of Harriet Tubman, Sakeem was empowered to open up and find the confidence to make the major changes he wanted in his life. After spending only one year at Harriet Tubman, Sakeem passed his first high school state assessment test – ever – an exciting personal accomplishment. Now, after voluntarily spending two of his summers on school work, Sakeem is on track to graduate this spring.

Other Ways You Can Help

Your contribution towards our Student Support Fund, and your help in sharing this campaign, will provide support to cover costs to which most of our student families cannot contribute. We strive to  create a learning environment that meets every child’s needs, and your support will help make that possible.

While large donations are helpful, a great number of small donations will also get us to our goal — every bit helps!

If you are unable to make a contribution at this time, please consider helping us spread the word to other potential donors. Greater recognition for our campaign will go a long way to helping us reach out goal!

Challenges

Harriet Tubman does not receive any government funding. Yet with the growing number of students coming to us from low-income families, our revenue balance has shifted dramatically away from tuition-paying students. We require support from individuals in the wider community if the school is to continue to serve this population by helping them graduate high school. 

Nationwide, people are realizing that there are many children who simply cannot learn in traditional schools. This is particularly true for students from low-income families who cannot afford to pay for the individual extra help of a tutor or small classrooms in a private school. The drop-out rate is alarmingly high, especially for low-income students of color. Equal access to all educational opportunities is beneficial to our entire community, as it allows our youth to support themselves through better employment and encourages them to make other positive life choices.

 

Our experience tells us that many children need small, community-based schools such as Harriet Tubman Democratic High School. For those who want to encourage the movement of non-traditional schools, or democratic education in particular, consider the power of helping Harriet Tubman demonstrate how alternative educational philosophies provide quality education to every child, from all walks of life.

story:
Who We Are

AFS-USA (formerly the American Field Service) is a leader in intercultural learning and offers exchange programs in more than 40 countries around the world.

Our mission is to work toward a more just and peaceful world by providing intercultural learning experiences to individuals, families, schools, and communities worldwide.

What We Need

$10,000 to help 5 U.S. high school students achieve their dreams of studying abroad.

Often, a $2,000 scholarship is all it takes to make studying abroad a reality for a deserving teen. It can mean the difference between a student staying home or taking part in a transformative experience that will help him or her become a global citizen – a culturally savvy young adult prepared to tackle 21st century challenges with maturity, empathy and an open mind.

“That’s how the world works…you take some, and then you give some”

Your donation not only gives a student like Dakin the gift of an open mind, lifelong friendships and bright prospects, but it also help perpetuate global citizenship development.

Upon receiving the gift of a scholarship, students give the gift of empathy and global awareness to all those they come in contact with abroad. Many also go on to support future students in pursuing study abroad opportunities. 

Contribution Karma (A.K.A. Perks)

In short, your gift helps inspire young people to make the world a better, more peaceful place. What does that mean for you? Good Karma, of course! And perhaps a little something extra…

$25: AFS Mad Lib $100: AFS Luggage Tag



$250: AFS Tote Bag $500: AFS "Kaffe" Mug

          


$1,000: "InterCOOLtural" T-Shirt $2,000: AFS "Peace" Sweatshirt


About our Students

AFS-USA scholarship recipients are:

  • Ages 14 - 18 years old
  • From both urban and rural communities
  • Chosen based on their commitment to community service and potential for leadership

Many AFS-USA study abroad participants go on to cultivate successful careers in internationally-relevant fields. All acquire global competency and 21st century skills to help them thrive in our increasingly interconnected world.

About Our Programs

The Impact of Study Abroad

AFS participant-based studies, as well as independent research, have confirmed the many tangible and long-term benefits of studying abroad:

(Click on the image above to enlarge)

AFS Study Abroad Programs

The average cost of an AFS-USA High School Year Program is $14,950. This includes:

Professional guidance and support throughout the process, from application through the completion of the program; Placement with a carefully selected volunteer host family and in a host school or community service organization; Round-trip international travel with your AFS Group between the international departure city in the US to the host country; Orientations prior to departure and after arrival on program; Comprehensive secondary medical insurance; Visa support and application assistance; Access to a support network of AFS Professional Staff in the US and in the host country, as well as thousands of trained volunteers worldwide; 24 hour emergency assistance.

Learn more about what tuition covers.

The AFS History

A Legacy of Volunteerism

AFS Intercultural Programs was founded in 1947 by members of the American Field Service, a volunteer ambulance driver corps in WWI and WWII. American Field Service drivers paid their own way overseas, bought their own uniforms, and risked their lives to help transport hundreds of thousands of wounded soldier to safety from both sides of the battlefields.

Leaders in Global Education

When the wars ended, the corps decided that its new charge should be to prevent future conflicts by promoting understanding among nations. They established AFS Intercultural Programs to help facilitate cross-cultural student exchanges that would enhance empathy and build cultural awareness worldwide. Today, AFS has a presence in more than 50 countries and facilitates exchanges between more than 90 countries. AFS-USA, the network's largest partner, annually sends nearly 1,000 students abroad and hosts more than 2,000 foreign exchange students in communities across the U.S.

In 2014 and 2015, we are celebrating the Centennial of the American Field Service and the spirit of volunteerism that lives on in AFS today. Thank you for your support as we head into the next 100 years!
story_txt:
Who We Are
AFS-USA (formerly the American Field Service) is a leader in
intercultural learning and offers exchange programs in more than 40 countries
around the world. 
Our mission is to work toward a more just and peaceful world
by providing intercultural learning experiences to individuals, families,
schools, and communities worldwide.


What We Need
$10,000 to help 5 U.S. high school students achieve their dreams of
studying abroad. 
Often, a $2,000 scholarship is all it takes to make studying
abroad a reality for a deserving teen. It can mean the difference between a
student staying home or taking part in a transformative experience that will
help him or her become a global citizen – a culturally savvy young adult prepared
to tackle 21st century challenges with maturity, empathy and an open
mind.


“That’s how the world works…you take some, and
then you give some”
Your donation not only gives a student like Dakin the gift
of an open mind, lifelong friendships and bright prospects, but it also help
perpetuate global citizenship development.
Upon receiving the gift of a scholarship, students give
the gift of empathy and global awareness to all those they come in contact with
abroad. Many also go on to support future students in pursuing study abroad
opportunities. 
Contribution Karma (A.K.A. Perks)
In short, your gift helps inspire young people to make the
world a better, more peaceful place. What does that mean for you? Good
Karma, of course! And perhaps a little something extra…



$25: AFS Mad Lib
$100: AFS Luggage Tag














$250: AFS Tote Bag
$500: AFS "Kaffe" Mug

In 2014 and 2015, we are celebrating the Centennial of the American Field Service and the spirit of volunteerism that lives on in AFS today. Thank you for your support as we head into the next 100 years!

story:
Who We Are, What We Do

For the last 12 years, working out of one tiny classroom, Ratbu Satarova has changed her small corner of the world for the better.  Ratbu lives and works in the small village of Tokotgul, Kyrgyzstan.  Because of Toktogul's small size and remote location (5-8 hours from the capital), students and teachers often have trouble accessing information (scholarships, newer textbooks, ESL resources) and training (new teaching methods, computers and internet, youth leadership) available to those living closer to the capital.  

Recognizing these needs in her community, Ratbu has written grants and partnered with volunteers locally and internationally to organize more than 20 projects for her community over the last 12 years for more than 300 teachers and students in Toktogul. These projects, run out of Ratbu's tiny classroom, have helped students grow into community leaders,  shown teachers how to create fun and research-driven lessons, and given kids with disabilities the chance to show their community all the amazing things they CAN do.  This room has become an indispensable resource to the people of Ratbu's village. 

What We Need 

But now we need your help.  Ratbu's room and work have been growing steadily, and last year she moved her little room into a slightly bigger room that will be a more permanent headquarters and can accommodate the growing numbers of people that want to work with her on her projects.  

The room (which will be the first wheelchair-accessible place in town) is almost ready to go, but needs a few final improvements before Ratbu can host workshops there.  So here's what we need:

  • Water:  $1,900
We plan to serve people with physical disabilities who often cannot carry buckets of water or use outdoor toilets without assistance.  Indoor plumbing will help this group feel much more comfortable in our classroom.


  • Heat:  $1,200
Kyrgyzstan winters are on par with Vermont winters, but buildings in Kyrgyzstan do not come automatically wired with heat.  Many households heat only one small room with an electric heater, and in many classrooms, children simply leave their winter coats on in their classrooms.  Since Ratbu's workshops sometimes need to accommodate more than 30 people, small electric heaters are simply not adequate, and radiator heat throughout the building is necessary.

  • Wheelchair Ramp:  $300

Many children stay home from school simply because their wheelchairs cannot fit through the doors to their school.  With help from this project, Ratbu's classroom will be the first building in town where kids bound to a wheelchair can come right up to the front door without any barriers.

  • Wi-Fi Modem:  $60
  • Wi-Fi for six months:  $120

Since Toktogul does not have an internet cafe, many of our students are at a disadvantage when competing for scholarships and study abroad programs against kids from the capital who have internet cafes on every corner.  With help from this project, Ratbu can install a modem and purchase some time online to help our students see what's beyond their small village.

  • Toilet Repairs:  $550

Our outdoor toilet needs repair to make it usable and comfortable for our visitors.

  • IndieGoGo's Admin Fee: $170

What You Get

We have lots of fun perks in addition to the good feeling you'll get when you help our cause.  Some highlights include:

  • Your name immortalized in song by the inimitable Max and Britta
  • Traditional Kyrgyz felt handicrafts (handmade by our kids)
  • Max wears a plunger on his head
  • Kyrgyz children elaborate on your "moxie" and "hustle"
  • ...and many more!

The Impact

Your donation will be the latest chapter of a long history of support for Ratbu's amazing work in the community of Toktogul.  With the continued support of community members and organizations from abroad, Ratbu has turned the generous donations she's received so far into something even more valuable---a community of teachers, parents, and students that has gown to be ever more knowledgeable in computers and English, that has developed strong leadership skills, and that has grown to encourage and support each other to work for the greater good of the community.  (Check out the detailed list of Ratbu's work here.) Your support will augment Ratbu's ability to continue this work in her community and make her small corner of the world a better place.


    Other Ways You Can Help

    If anything in our story has struck a chord with you, please contribute.  You can make a cash donation, purchase one of our perks, or spread the word to everyone you know by checking out our website, liking us on Facebook and especially sharing this link on your own Facebook page.  We hope to hear from you soon!

story:
Summary

Friends!

My wife Verena and I are asking you to contribute to this special school project we have set our focus on.  You will ask why?  We met JeanBaptiste, also called Pierre, in Ruhengeri in August of 2013, when he was 12 years old. He assisted us in getting to the market where we bought a traditional basket.  Later we contacted Pierre’s school principal by email to see how we could support Pierre who wants to become a medical doctor. Pierre and his school principal only asked for $10 to cover his expenses for the upcoming school term to which we agreed.  After much correspondence and gathering of information on this school we decided we want to help more and got involved with this large school with over 2,000 students.  There is a real need for several items, but we have decided on the computers first.  Connecting these students to the world of learning and information will boost their futures.  Jean de Dieu, the school principal, has set his mind on the computers as it will make learning much easier and more universal.  Just imagine the internet resources these students can access to improve their learning and world view.  The school has only a few desktops right now, but with the 27 computer stations we envision funding, the principal can introduce full computer classes to his students.  Please assist in this endeavor with a monetary contribution of your choice.

See the attached quote from a Kigali Computer supplier and installer showing the Rwandan Francs amount, we need to collect.  In US Dollars this is about $13,000.  My wife and I will personally cover the 4% fee to Indiegogo.

For more detailed information, please look at the attached documents and photos.

The Costs

 


The Impact

 


 

 

SPREAD THE WORD!!

story:
Poetry Slam Camp at GAC!

In 2012, we were approached by Gustavus Adolphus College in Minnesota to create a one-of-a-kind academic summer camp for high school students who love slam poetry.  Our institute invites all high-school-age students to join expert instructors for a weeklong intensive of reading, writing, editing and performing spoken word poetry.  If you are a high school student who loves poetry--regardless of talent or experience--we hope you check out our website (https://gustavus.edu/camps/slamcamp/) and join us the last week of June in Saint Peter, MN.

Your Support Matters!

Parents, friends, fellow mentors, and patrons of poetry: we need your help to make our camp as cost-effective as possible for families in need.  Although our camp is about half the cost of many similar academic camps we want to ensure that our institute is affordable for every student who wants to attend.  We also need help hiring additional mentoring artists and covering administration costs.

Each year, our camp has been a life-changing experience for both students and our staff. With your help we can make a transformative experience available to more young people in need of an arts space that they can call their own.  Help us help the next generation learn to speak for themselves!

Help Us Reach Our Goal!

With your help we hope to raise 6000 dollars to make our camp as amazing of an experience as possible.  With your donations, we hope to:

  • Create 3000 dollars of scholarships for students in need to help cover tuition costs (such as food and board) and travel expenses.
  • Use 1500 to hire additional instructors, lecturers, guest performers, and help counselors from out of town cover the costs of travel
  • Use 1500 to cover administrative and promotional expenses

For our generous donors, we have two exciting perks to say thank you:

  • For donations of 50 dollars or more, we will send you our 2014 class chapbook of poetry written by students attending our institute.
  • For donations of 200 dollars or more, we will create a scholarship in your name (or the name of your choosing.  Donors at this level will also receive a hand-written letter from your sponsored student and our class chapbook.

If for some reason we are unable to meet our goal (or if we exceed it), half of the raised funds will go toward student scholarships, a fourth will go towards hiring additional mentors and a fourth will go toward administrative costs.

If you have any questions about camp or the fundraiser, feel free to email the camp's director Adam Henze at adamhenze@gmail.com.

Other Ways You Can Help!

We understand that not everyone can help us monetarily, but there are other ways that you can help us in our mission:

  • If there is a high-school-age writer or performer in your life, please tell them know about the amazing opportunity of our camp!
  • Please help us get the word out about our campaign by sharing our fundraiser on social media and e-mailing it to friends and family!
  • Support our partner Button Poetry: make sure you like Button Poetry on Facebook, follow them on Twitter, and visit their YouTube page. 

If the young writer in your life is too young for our camp, Gustavus Adolphus College also has a camp for younger writers (https://gustavus.edu/camps/writers/).  For more questions about GAC and its academic programs, please e-mail the director of academic camps Kris Kracht at kkracht@gustavus.edu.

Thank you for your support!

story:
Before the introduction of myself, please allow me to thank you wholeheartedly for reading this page.

I understand thant many of you might be having a thought along the lines of "Why should I give any of my money to this guy! Just so he can learn to fly, what a crock. There are so many children, in third world countries, whom need education, clean water, medical care, and food." If so Please, for the love of all that is good, do it! I know i'll get by without any help but these kids won't. They need your money first and I appreciate that you would provide them with life giving services. 

Here is a list of charities I feel worthy of your funding.

www.msf.org.au - Médecins Sans Frontières (Doctors Without Borders)

www.ewb.org.au - Engineers Without Borders

www.savethechildren.org.au - Save The Children

www.hollows.org.au - Fred Hollows Foundation

www.rspcansw.org.au - RSPCA, Puppies and kitties need help too.


But if you still don't mind giving me a few bob.

My name is Dane Cook and I have always had the dream to become a pilot. At first, when I was a small child it was to fly large fixed wing machines like 747's or 320's but have grown to fear the repetitiveness and bordom that comes with flying sky buses. My interests have moved toward the Helicopter and now i am going to make this dream come true. If you can help I greatly appreciate it!

What I Need...

To get a Commercial Helicopters Pilots Licence (CPL(H)) the basic requirements are time and money. I have the time... but this is where the rest of the world comes in!

  • To learn to fly a helicopter it costs $510-$550 an hour and to get a CPL(H). A student needs somewhere between 125 - 150 hours to become profficient enough to get a licence. That equates to between $63,750 - $82,500. The amount I am asking for now would pay for 10 hours which is a small amount of the overall time but it is a very big help.
  • If I don't reach my goal within this campaign I will still be very happy with the kindness and generosity offered and the money will still help me on my way to achieving this goal!

Other Ways You Can Help...

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please tell your friends and share this link. If I just have 530 people share $10 with me, this is an easily achievable goal!
  • And don't forget to use Indiegogo's page sharing tools!

Thank You again for coming, reading and giving support.
P.S. - If you have given me $10, please also give $10 to one of the above charities. I know you can afford it...
